RATING: 8.9
Like Concept, this game can be figured out on the fly in about a minute by anyone who wants to join in. Unlike Concept, some more advanced (but still very intuitive) thought processes can ensure better victory conditions. So simple yet, the possibility of advanced analysis is there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Some thoughts I had after two different evenings (6-7 games): Neat game, but overpriced for what you get. By the end of the first evening, a couple of us had figured out that the game turns and sort of breaks when you get someone as a codemaster who is really good at concept association (and thus good at being the ghost in Mysterium, the clue giver in Concept, etc). The people who just did straight association of words (e.g. "Musicians, 2" and yields "Kid, Rock") had a much rougher/tense go at it than the people who did conceptual linking to examples (e.g. "Jurisdiction, 6" and ended up with London, New York, Australia, Bermuda, etc which just sort of ends the game). The difference is you can still get screwed by interpretation of the dream cards in Mysterium (or just get a shitty draw) where as it just sort of falls over here. Reminds me of Set in that regard (where skill imbalance is a key factor). Second, the game dragged ass above 9 players. The discussion phase lags because you're waiting in lock step for a clue to be given where as in Mysterium you can be working on someone else's clue while you wait for your own. Our best games we had in that regard were at 5p, maybe 6p. Above that, and I'd probably break up into two groups and play something else. I think one of the most telling things is that with Mysterium, we played that until they made us go home every week for like 6 weeks, where as this, we played for maybe 2 hours and everyone was ready for something new after just the first week (both groups on different days even...) It's a game I'll play if it shows up (and there isn't anything else to play right off hand), but I'd never buy it.

almost a year later, I find it's just ok, but it improves some if you use dixit cards instead of words which is where I think Mysterium achieves a better "group guess the interpretation" setup. Baring that, I think it should be a requirement that there are no single guess clues.

RATING: 4
[I]tl;dr -  This one got a lot of hype, but it really depends on the group and can easily get overplayed. The basic concept of giving clues is really good, though.[/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Codenames is a fairly fun social game but I'm not as high on it as most people are. The best part of the game is being the spymaster, but if you're playing with any more than four players, going around to let everyone be the spymaster takes a LONG time. I feel like not getting to be the spymaster is kind of lame, but that must be the only way people are playing this with 10+ people. 

The basic game structure is fine, but this one flaw means that games are either unsatisfying for many people, or take way too long for the game offered. I also find the game very repetitive after one session of 2-3 rounds, so I only like this one every so often. Unfortunately, our group loves it so even though I don't own it, we play it a lot. 

[b]The basic spymaster concept is implemented much better in [thing=224037][/thing], since both players get to be a spymaster[/b] -- its become the go-to two-player game for my wife and I, and I highly recommend it.

RATING: 7
10 plays / 6,7,8 players

LIKE: Solid game, easy to learn. Good variation between plays.
DISLIKE: Rules of silence are important and inadvertently broken. Game is a bit light and needs the right group.

OVERALL: Fun game for a group, because the team aspect creates that tension and interesting dynamics. I don't think it'd be as fun with less than 6.

RATING: 6.5
Alright. I like it too. It's a nice challenge as the spy master. Conversely, if you are listening to bad clues, it's very frustrating. It's tempting to give precise clues for 1 card as if slow and steady wins the day - and often enough, the game reduces to just this. But with a bit of stretching, you can get more than 1 clue done. And better, you can mentally file away past clues to surge ahead later. Certainly approachable. Good for a group of 4+. Will I put it into my collection? Hmm. Difficult to say.

RATING: 7
I do not know which is more fun, playing the spymaster given hints or trying to figure out the clues. Either way Codenames is entertaining. The only worry I have about the game is the possibility for serious analysis paralysis with some players if they just cannot make up good hints. Fortunately the publisher has supplied the players with an hourglass to keep the pace fast.

Anyways, Codenames certainly lives to its rating offering superb party fun for the early evening when the going is not too crazy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I had heard a lot of buzz around this game before I got the chance to play it, and at the time I didn't get what all the excitement was about.  Having now played it, I have to say... I still don't get it.  Well, maybe I can see why other people like it, but it just doesn't do it for me.

The game is very thin on theme which, being a Eurogamer, doesn't usually bother me so long as the game is interesting mechanically, but this one falls flat in that regard as well.  This game is highly prone to analysis paralysis if you don't use a timer (which I didn't in any of my plays), resulting in most players sitting around doing nothing while one or a small portion of players thinks long and hard.  The play time on the box says 15 minutes, but our games took more like 30, and it felt like more than 30 due to the down time.  There's very little thinking or planning you can do outside of your own turn unless you are a clue-giver, which makes the down time more pronounced.

The limitation of single word clues is highly restrictive, and trying to give clues about a randomly selected group of words is even more restrictive.  It's extremely difficult to come up with clues that will lead to more than 2 answers unless the board favors such clues, and even if you could come up with such a clue, odds are it would be so obscure or convoluted that your teammate(s) would never guess it.  Typically the best you can hope to accomplish in a turn is to get two answers correct, usually with the second one being a bit of a toss-up.  I usually agree with the adage that restrictions breed creativity, but the restrictions in this game feel so much so that it chokes out creativity.

Additionally, it's very hard to carry any information over from turn to turn.  Usually you will find the clues your teammate was going for, meaning you are back to square one the next round.  Blindly guessing is not a valid strategy except in desperate situations as you can hit an opponent's word or, worse, hit the assassin and lose straight out (which is not only disappointing for the losing team, but is a rather lame way to win).

I generally find Vlaada Chvatil games overly fiddly with an excessive number of rules, and while I don't find this game fiddly, I do find it too confining.  I don't know whether it would be better off with more rules or less, but I do know this isn't a game for me.  If I want to play a game that involves giving clues and trying to think like someone else, I will reach for Dixit or Mysterium instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

(-) Meat of the game is only enjoyed by the clue givers, can be lots of downtime when waiting on clues (no one likes using the timer)

RATING: 9
Everyone loves it! We have twice used it as the main game at parties (with very mixed groups of people) and it was a success both times. A few of the attendees later purchased the game for themselves. I have played it with older folks who are not gamers at all and they loved it. I have even played it with teenagers and children under 10 and they wanted to go 20 rounds for each team. It's a great little game (as long as you don't have any cheaters--Dad!) and the huge variety of words makes it very non-repetitive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What's this?  A party game that is enjoyable?  Yes, sir!

This one can be really dependent on the base intelligence of the group you are playing with.  Smart people can come up with some remarkably clever clues (even though they are only one word!) that are a thing of beauty, based on references to history, literature, etc.

Other groups?  I could see this falling flat (unless there happens to be that one time where the clue giver could say, "Animals, 4" and have all of the animal words conveniently lined up).  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A very easy game to teach and plays very quick and can fit a big group. It is one of those games where a review does not do it justice till you play it. It is immensely interactive and interestingly even when it is not your team's turn you are constantly discussing old clues and planning whether to push your luck with another clue if you are leading or trailing in the game. 
Downsides are firstly, the clue giver is under the spotlight and there is stress as the whole team depends on how you come up with clues. Also, more vocal players will dominate the game over quieter ones especially in bigger groups. 
Overall though such a simple game but yet so good I played 6 games in a row and still would not have minded to play more. Highly recommended.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 4.5
I'm a little confused by the amount of popularity that this game has. I will give it credit for having made something new out of a really simple concept, but on the other hand I don't really see what all the fuss is about.  I think it's an enjoyable mental exercise, but this game is not crazy, it's not loud, it's not funny... I don't really see how it would work in a party atmosphere. 

I like the fact that Codenames is a cooperative game. It kinda reminds me of Mysterium, which is a game I really like, and yet, since there are words instead of pictures, usually the guessing part is pretty straight-forward and not as fun. That wouldn't be so bad actually though, if it wasn't for the fact that this game has A LOT of downtime. You sit there watching people thinking to come up with a clue and then listen to other people thinking out loud about what that clue could mean. Then finally it's your turn and you do the exact same thing. 

So I don't particularly enjoy Codenames and I really can't see how this could work in a party-like situation. Apparently I just don't see in this box what many other people see. For me it's boring and really too slow and long for what it is.

RATING: 8
1st plays: Played a few games with the wife in 2p, and I was surprised at how much it plays well with 2.  I'm sure the sweet spot is 6, or maybe 4, but it really does work well with 2.  I don't know how this game didn't exist before, but it's excellent.

2nd plays: Played with gamers and 3p, as a Co-op racing the AI player.  Even better, the moments as you listen to the field agents discussing the clue and pointing at the wrong clue is so enjoyable.  The moment when you realize they've made a logic leap you didn't see coming, and trying to mentally avert the crisis.  And as the field agent, trying to figure out what the heck the clue actually means!

RATING: 6
I almost feel bad rating this a six because it's saved me from hours of torment playing the various terrible Apples to Apples derivatives (Cards Against Humanity, etc.) but due to its nature it's not something I want to play when I want to play games. I play it at parties. Unfortunately, I never actually want to play games at parties, I just do it because other people like to. 

So, on the one hand I sort of dislike Codenames because I don't consider it up to snuff to play at an actual game night with other hobbyists, but on the other hand I love Codenames because it allows me to cut down on the amount of time I spend playing absolute trash. I guess that boils down to a resounding vote of "OK." I also only paid seven bucks for that so it's more palatable to own it as a defensive measure. I would never have purchased it if friends of mine didn't insist on bringing out terrible games at parties.

I also rate Taboo a six and that's basically the mirror version of this game. 

The components are rather poor. The cardboard tokens are fine but the cards are flimsy and the key has the cards portrayed as square rather than rectangular which is just bad design.

RATING: 6
People like it. I find it somewhat amusing to play as the spy master and to try and come up with clue. But outside of that, there's not really much game to this game. I'm thinking this one is going to fade away pretty quickly. I smell fad. We'll see.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Codenames is a team game. Each team's spy master knows the solution to the puzzle and must provide clues to their team in order that they can solve it quicker than their opponents.  An assassin, who can bring your round to a sudden end, adds some spice.  The difficulty for the spy master lies in offering clues that link multiple correct words, but no incorrect ones.  It all works fine.  I like it slightly better as a four-player than with larger groups and it is definitely more interesting to take the spy master role.  All the same,  this kind of puzzle-ish exercise doesn't excite me.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Πολυδιαφημισμένο party game από τον δημοφιλή Vlaada. Ο λαός λέει πως όπου ακούς πολλά κεράσια, κράτα και μικρό καλάθι, όμως το Codenames καταφέρνει και lives up to the hype. Οι κανόνες είναι πολύ απλοί. Οι παίκτες χωρίζονται σε 2 ομάδες και ορίζουν από ένα αρχηγό. Τοποθετούμε στο τραπέζι τυχαία 25 κάρτες/λέξεις και τραβάμε μια κάρτα που δείχνει στους αρχηγούς ποιες από τις 25 λέξεις είναι δικές τους. 

Σκοπός των παικτών της κάθε ομάδας είναι να βρουν πρώτοι ποιες είναι οι δικές τους λέξεις, ακολουθώντας τα στοιχεία που δίνει ο αρχηγός. Ωραία προσθήκη είναι και η ύπαρξη μιας λέξης βόμβας που αν μια ομάδα πέσει πάνω της, χάνει αμέσως το παιχνίδι. Προφανώς και παίζει σημαντικό ρόλο η επιλογή αρχηγού στο τελικό αποτέλεσμα. 

Τα components είναι απλά και λειτουργικά ενώ σημαντικό είναι πως οι λέξεις που διάλεξαν έχουν διπλή σημασία ώστε οι αρχηγοί να μπορούν να βρίσκουν έξυπνους συνδυασμούς. Φυσικά θα ήταν καλύτερα αν το παιχνίδι ήταν στα ελληνικά. Ελπίζω να βγει σύντομα μια ελληνική έκδοση.

Δεν χρησιμοποιήσαμε καθόλου την κλεψύδρα που παρέχεται στο κουτί αλλά μπορώ εύκολα να φανταστώ κάποιους που σαν αρχηγοί θα θέλανε κανένα μισάωρο για να δώσουν clue.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players: 2-8
Time: 15 min

In Codenames, two teams compete to see who can make contact with all of their agents first. Spymasters give one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team. And everyone wants to avoid the assassin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Two spymasters are attempting to contact their agents in the field, but communication is cryptic and limited. Twenty-five words are laid out in a grid which corresponds to a secret cipher only the spymasters can see. Hints are given which comprise a single word and a single number, indicating a clue that ties a certain number of words on the table together to be guessed. The first team to guess all of their words wins. It's very possible to pick your opposing team's words, neutral words, or the insta-lose Assassin word rather than your own. Be careful!

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
This is both a party game and not a part game. Great for big groups or 2v2. I don't like most party games, so this is a great niche-filler for me. The most interesting part of this game is the meta/lack of meta between the players. I might know a perfect clue for one person, but I have to consider the whole team. Just the same, a word I think is the right answer was totally missed by the spymaster, leading to hilarity and facepalming for everyone.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
As with any guessing game with a time limit, you can get choked up and induce the ire of your teammates. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Thanks 2015 BGG Secret Santa!!!

RATING: 8
This game appears fairly easy on first sight. The setup is very fast, the rules are plain and easy to grasp. Playing is fun and a lot trickier than you might think. The combinations of words on the double sided cards are sheer endless, so it has an extremely high replayability. It will not ever get boring. Playing with 2 players is do-able and fun, but you will really enjoy it with more. It is a perfect party game. You start to play in an instant and the fast rounds are really immensely entertaining.

RATING: 10

I would call this a "Gamer's Party Game".  You have to meta the crowd and think about what they might know and be very creative with clues to gain tempo on the other team.

Updated 11/9: Moved to 10.  After more replays, it is apparent that this game is a hit and everyone enjoys it.  Another side benefit is that people can hop in/out of the game while waiting for a "meatier" game.  It is almost always being played at our board game nights at any given time.

RATING: 8
It has been said of this game... why wasn't this thought of before.  And that is an excellent summary of the reaction most will have to this game.  It's a simple, simple game.  Executed with simplicity and yet so rewarding to play.  It scales with players and skills remarkably well.  It's approachable by gamers and casual players alike.  This is the kind of game one expects to see in the mass market and its entirely likely that it might get there.  And for the world at large, that's great because so is the game.  If you are looking for a word game or a party game that will rope the players in and have folks laughing and enjoying themselves regardless of gamer status, look no further.  A smart and spot on game design worthy of an award of two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.7
I'm not a big fan of these sorts of word games (Password, etc), so I'm not 100% on board the hype train for this, but it's nevertheless great that Vlaada has come along and more or less destroyed them with a superior game. Lots of potential here depending on who you play with, what clues you can think up, and the various placement schemata that the Spymasters have to work from. Inclusion of the Assassin ensures a game can end quickly. Good stuff, glad they have variants too, though I'd prefer to play with the Firm word rules because I feel like letting too many random judgement calls on homonyms and such will soil up a session.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I tend to dislike shorter games, there are other things that I'd much rather be spending my time doing.  However, if you need a shorter game as a filler, or a party game, this is one of the better ones.  You can teach it in 5 minutes, it works well with a varying number of players, and it's relatively inexpensive.

The theme is the most irrelevant that I've seen lately.  This is just a word association game.

RATING: 6
A very good "thinky" party game. The puzzle is really there (especially for the code giver), and there's a lot of interaction.

On the downside, it tends to be a long game for what it is, as the puzzles can be really tough.

UPDATE: I finally got why I don't like this game as much as I should (given it's a design by Vlaada, and an elegant, thinky party game). It's a "party game for introverts": an exercise in trying to read someone else, while politely arguing with your partners. For me, a party game must be loud and funny. Codenames is a decent deduction exercise, but a rather boring party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Zseniális!! Magasan a legjobb asszociációs partijáték szerintem. Sőt talán a legjobb partijáték, amivel valaha játszottam. Mindennél többet elmond, hogy az esseni játékújdonságoktól körülvéve is 6 partit lenyomtunk egyhuzamban. Mondjuk ez nem feltétlen jelent sok időt, volt 2 perces parti is, de a leghosszabb se volt 25 percnél több. A játék lényege, hogy egy szóval egyszerre minél több -az asztalon lévő- szóra utaljunk. Egyszerű, rövid, szerintem lehengerlő. Ezek után miért activitiznék valaha is az életben? Egyetlen hátránya, hogy (még?!) nincs magyar kiadás, mert ez igazán magyarul lenne jó. Örülök, hogy Chvatil nem csak komplex játékot tud jót csinálni.
Megjegyzés: körönként 2 szót 100%-os biztonsággal ki lehet találni egy elég faék sportszerűtlen módszerrel, de egyrészt ez megöli a játékot, másrészt nem is feltétlen nyerő, ha az ellenfél 2-nél többet tud átlagosan behúzni.
---
3 fővel is tökéletesen működik, bár így igazából csak ketten versenyeznek.

RATING: 7
Entertaining family-filler-party game.  The objective is to discover the right words in a matrix of cards through just a one word key.  Ideally, with the key, you would try to guess the largest number of words, but it is certainly difficult to give such good keys to relate words usually with nothing in common.
Very easy, it has quite a big part of psichology, as in Dixit and similar games.

07.02.03.03
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vlada Chvátil is the most versatile, ingenious and inspired designer of boardgames in the market nowadays.
He is capable of crafting the most complex of the gamer's games (Through the Ages, Mage Knight), alongside funny designs (Space Alert, Galaxy Trucker) and now even on of the best party games ever.

Codenames is so simple and elegant, one would wonder why it wasn't already invented. Two teams of players compete to be the first in identifying every agent of their color. One player in each team must craft clues (using exactly one word and one number) to help teammates understanding behind which codename their agents are hiding.

The game is an exercise in lateral thinking, and the role of the spymaster is quite challenging: clues that group more than 2-3 words are definitely hard to find.

Codenames is one of those games you hardly abandon after just one game. Or after two or three...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My wife loves it. I like it. We've found it's a game that is great no matter who is around. Be sure to have the people who are the most familiar with the game be the spymaster for your first session or two before passing spymaster to people unfamiliar with the game, as that will make the game go better for everyone.

Edit: May 2017. As my wife and I continue exploring games, this game doesn't get played. We prefer more strategic options; K2/Via Nebula has been our "gateway" weight game of choice; and Junk Art is our light/party game of choice. There's still room on the shelf for this game, though, as it provides a unique experience, and is great at higher player counts. I am probably rating this a bit low, since it is very successful at what it intends to be. My rating, however, is an accurate reflection of my overall desire to play this game.

Edit: November 2017. After playing Codenames: Duet, I'm not sure we'd ever play the base version of Codenames again. Duet seems like a straight improvement to Codenames. This version will like be used a source of additional cards for Duet moving forward.

RATING: 10
Je vormt een team met ke partner, en je moet uitzoeken welke kaartjes (met schuilnamen) tot je team behoren.
Je partner zegt een zelfstandig naamwoord of een eigennaam en een getal x.  Jij weet dan dat je x kaartjes kan raden die gerelateerd zijn tot het gezegde woord.
Pas wel op dat je geen kaartjes noemt van het andere team, want dat geeft hen een voorsprong natuurlijk.
En pas al helemaal op dat je de zwarte kaart niet noemt, want dan stopt het spel onmiddellijk.

Gespeeld met NL talig prototype in nov 2015.  Zou binnenkort uitkomen in het NL.

RATING: 3
The group I played had this special way of giving clues – it totally feels like cheating, and nothing like the (supposedly) intended way to play.
Instead of giving a smart answer that may link to several words, they just built chain-words that made no sense, but each part of the chain clearly linked to a card on the table.

So, one can argue that my rating is heavily influenced by the group I played with.

Nevertheless I think that the Spiel des Jahres jury got the nomination for this game wrong. The nature of the game relies so strong on language that players' age factors in heavily => not a typical family game.

RATING: 7

It is a really interesting challenge trying to find a 1 word guess that ties in more than one of your words.  At the moment I am terrible at giving the clues but there is plenty of fun here.  You do need to be able to come up with clues in the clue giver role for this game to work.  Also in a round there is a bit of a runaway leader problem as it is very hard to catch up in a round.  Still glad to have it, happy to play it.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After three plays I have a better grasp on commenting. A clever game that demands that the players are clever as well. The Spymaster must be on top of their game and I have witnessed a team's frustration when a clue word 'could' match more than the offered number and it was clear these other tie ins had been missed completely by the SM. Game is greatly assisted by the app timer. Rounds are quick so down time when its not you turn is minimal. Fun filler, certainly well thought out and tee'd up nicely for expansion decks in perpetuity. Could be an awesome experience with sharp players, will be dire with less competent players. Pick players and Spymasters wisely.

Follow on games show that the card array is 80% responsible for and enjoyable or dire game. The joy of cleverly connecting 3-4 words is massively offset by the torture of a game where not a single connection can be found. This is hell for the spy master and the team. Just to compound the angst, the game seems to compell post game autopsies where smug players say 'you should have said.....' where their offering makes no sense at all. Not really fussed if I ever play this again and certainly not a game I'd want to buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
I have to admit this is a truly great party game, and one that will be added to my collection at some point. However, the end game isn't so spectacular. In a close match it, and most should be, it comes down to either taking a chance for the win or handing it over to your opponents to see what they can do. So, while it's a good game that provides wonderful team puzzle solving and inspires great debate, the game just kind of ends. It's like Mysterium without having to solve the crime to win. Just wishing it had that something extra at the end to close it out with a bang instead of a whimper.

RATING: 8
Really engaging team-based word game that makes you think in a creative manner without it being too free form. Trying hard to connect as many words as possible for your teammates is a fun challenge, as is the struggle to decipher the one word clue given you by your spymaster. Incredibly unique, but be warned- "party game" is a bit of a misnomer. This is a little more contemplative than the typical party fare. It's mostly quiet, but can also inspire laughter likes it's lighter brothers and sister.

RATING: 9
One of my favorite party games.  I'm not normally a fan of word games, but this is so much more than a word game.  As a clue giver, one of the most rewarding experiences is when the single word the glues together three seemingly random things pops into your head.  You give the clue and suddenly your team has come from behind and stolen the game from the other team who only had one word left.

If you haven't played this game, go do it now!

RATING: 8
The word association mechanic in this game really appeals to me, particularly my literature-loving side. It's always a fun creative challenge trying to find the connections between disparate words. One opponent really wowed me once with "Basketball 5". It's a great game, but the box should actually read 3-8 players, because the two-player game is utterly hopeless. Given it's usually just my wife and I playing, I traded this away in anticipation of the release of Codenames Duet, designed especially for two.

RATING: 8
I was terrified to play this game because somehow I got the impression that it was a game similar to Dixit which requires creative clues based on almost nothing. That game infuriates me because I can't manufacture that kind of clue quickly, or effectively. I was pleased to discover that you actually have a lot to work with here in Codenames, and the challenge is more about figuring out simple links between multiple key words. I had a great time playing the game, and will probably seek it out again. I can see tell some people will not do as well as others when playing, and like-minded people might have an unfair advantage if teamed up together, but it's a great design that deserves all the attention it has received.

RATING: 2
6 Plays in with the family.  Found it very quiet, especially the first several minutes as the game.  The point of course is to have your teammates guess as many 'codenames' correctly with a single clue.  Maybe our groups were unimaginative or unlucky with the cards selected but many times it was a single codename for a single clue.  I was quite disappointed given the high rating of this game.  Might change it to a five with more plays but right now it sits at four.

EDIT:   A few more plays in , even less desire to play this game again.  No idea how this game is rated so well.  Lowering rating from 4 to 2 mostly as a protest to all of the high ratings.  Seriously feel somebody is paying for good reviews of this game.

RATING: 8
My second favorite party game we own (behind Sushi Go Party!). It is a hit at young adults game night we do through our church. The game is simple, easy to teach, and plays very quickly with the right group of people. My only real criticism with the game is it can be a bit too easy depending on the board, and I think going first doesn't have enough of a handicap to make up for the advantage. 

For this cost, size, and complexity, you really can't do much better than Codenames. Recommended for sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Christmas present 2015. This game is great game to bring to a party. The problem is if you suggest this game to group of non-gamers, the name suggest to them that this is tough on the brain or something. Once they start to play and get what is going on they really get into the game. 
A simple game, there are 2 teams (red or blue) that have one person calling out clues to their team members to have them guess and pick a set of cards with words on them that match a secret card with a grid of where the red or blue team cards are located. There is a huge stack of cards with words on both sides that are used to lay out a 5x5 grid. In the same grid of worded cards is a spy that if one of the team picks the spy then they lose. A lot of the words have similar meanings so giving a clue for a set of cards you want your team to guess might have them guess a card that is for the other team, or worse the Spy. Whichever team is the first to pick all their color's cards without revealing the spy is the winner. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The weaker alternative whenever a party game is to be chosen, Codenames relies heavily on the players' (and even more so a team leader's) skills at categorizing things to be enjoyable somehow. If such is your group, lucky you: moderate fun ensues.

With the typical boneheads that plague most game meetings though Codenames might lose any appeal quickly, as playing it becomes a slog soon. [i](August 2016)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - Actually, after repeated plays something clicked and suddenly Codenames has turned into a light game we all enjoy: the reason is explained easily, the group we’ve been playing it with has changed. When party and filler games are around, these new people are less competitive and don’t aim to look like the brightest bulbs around: they just want to have loud fun, which is what I’ve always been looking for too. Codenames benefited from such a change as well, as it showed how fit for our common playstyle it is.
Hence in January 2018 I’ve raised my rating from 6 to 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impressions:
----------------------
It's pretty amazing that such a simple idea can turn into such a fun game.  This game works really well, and I really think this would be a neat team building activity at work (might need to use this...).  I played first without being the clue giver, and was like "bah, this would be easy".  Boy was I wrong, it is super tough to be the clue giver, and when playing with a timer its super nerve raking!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Codenames is an easy to learn party game, but has enough depth to entertain serious gamers.

However, it suffers from excessive downtime.  The game design encourages clue givers to take their time giving clues to their time, forcing the other team to sit in silence for long periods of time.  The game comes with a optional timer, but people don't want to use it because it isn't a standard part of the game.



If you are looking for a light party game, I suggest Taboo, Dixit, or Telestrations. I only recommend playing this at parties because it does a good job of handing changing numbers of people.

I was a bit leery of this title owing to the hype, but I found it a very light and tight, short, thinky parlor game. I don't think it deserves the level of excitement that it has gained but I really, really dig it and I wouldn't let it leave my collection. The most fun part is the fun conversations of "How could you not get that?!?" and "That is crazy clever, Bill. Crazy. You are an alien." I will say that it definitely fires a whole host of lame 1980's games that tried to fill this niche. Recommended! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
To be honest I don't understand the hype surrounding this one. Its ok I guess...but at higher player counts why not just play dixit, and at lower player counts I much prefer mysterium or playing an actual board game.

EDIT: I don't know what changed...perhaps being buzzed on new years eve...but gave this game another shot and it came through. I very much enjoyed it this time around.

RATING: 7
I find it plays best when the group actually has two timers, so one is always ready to be flipped. Every time someone has mentioned to me that they don't understand how it falls so flatly with them, that it's a largely silent affair that simply ISN'T a party game, I ask and they invariably mention they didn't use the timer.

Well, sure. But the pressure that comes from the timer (applied to both on the spymaster and his guessers, hence the need for two timers) is what brings out the voices and the party-style nature of the game.

RATING: 10
Rarely does a game just click with all types of players but Codenames has done just that. Trying to figure out clues to give (or those given to you by a spymaster) and associate them correctly with the grid of 25 words is a great challenge that takes time to get good at. Plus it will be context dependent as certain players or teams will have different points of reference to rely on. This has earned the game of the year awards it received because while the game mechanic is incredibly simple, it opens up tons of replay ability and fun. 

Looking forward to many more games of this, and also trying variants.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just a fantastic party game--the best I've found. Don't take the scoring system too seriously or worry about being competitive. Just enjoy coming up with clever hints, and have a great time as the guessers argue vociferously over what the hints mean.

Very easy to teach new players. It's basically a surefire hit--I've introduced this to some wildly differing groups of people and it's been a hit every time. It works best with six people in two teams of three; seven or eight work fine too. You can also play a reasonable game with four or five, but then it starts losing some of its charm.

It's easy to bring to social events or play when space is limited. The box is small and lightweight and there aren't too many components.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I have too major complaints about this game. The first simply being too much downtime. Secondly, some people like to play where the clue giver can't react at all when they say yes to a clue because it would reveal that was the correctly associated word. This is a huge bummer for me and really defeats this games potential to be a good party game. Why play a "party" game that fails to encourage laughter and table-talk?

Overall, it doesn't live up to the hype, although these couple complaints don't kill the game for me. In fact, I can safely recommend this game after having seen so many people have a great time with it (also it's quite short and inexpensive).

It's a 6 as a clue giver and 7 as a guesser so I met it in the middle at 6.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First two games with 4 players. Fun as I expected and actually a bit of a brain burner. I can see this being even better with 6 or 8 players. Looking forward to many more plays.

Update 09/12: played many more 8+ player games at Gamealot 2015. Still a blast and a great party game. Lots of good 'stories' to tell when you've had a few rounds.

RATING: 8.75
Codenames has quickly become my favorite 'party game' to pull out when I have a group of people who aren't gamers.

One of the things that makes it shine is that as long as you have two people who have played before, you don't even have to explain the rules! I just set up the tiles, start, and explain as I go. This characteristic makes it very easy to get to the table.

The 2 player game is fun, but the 4+ player game is fantastic.

RATING: 9
What is there to say? This game has slowly taken over my table to the point that it gets played more than almost anything else. I haven't adjusted my rating on it in a while, and if I was going to, this could be rated a bit lower if only because I can get a bit burnt out on it. I think in a year though it will be hitting the table regularly but not at the near constant rate that it is now, at which point I would probably still rate it the same. This is a true crowd pleaser. The merits of the game have been well sung. I love that it's a more cerebral counterpart to a lot of the more raucous modern party games, a great addition to any game night with serious or non-serious gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game of limited communication, and its popularity was probably also helped by its incredibly accessible price point. However, that is not to say that Codenames isn't a fun, puzzle-y and sometimes agonisingly difficult party game. It certainly doesn't create a loud and riotous atmosphere, but the perfect time to play this game is either Christmas with the family or at the pub with friends - so it firmly sits in that category for me. The game has also been great as an icebreaker at new game groups too. Articulating exactly what makes this game so much better than the other games like it is very difficult - but the agony of choice and the in-jokes you can make with you friends around the table all go towards putting this in a league of its own. The final reason I love this game, and have racked up 70+ plays so far is how balanced every grid in the game is. It possibly sounds daft to say it, but a hell of a lot of playtesting must have gone in to selecting all the words in the box - to the point where the mechanically identical Codenames: Deep Undercover is nowhere near as enjoyable, because it is too hard to create tenuously successful combos, because all the words in that edition are a bad combination of being far too similar or completely disparate ideas (or parts of the anatomy). Codenames, however, hits the nail right on the head. There always seems to be a risk that you'll reveal the assassin but you're very rarely so stumped for links that you have to resort to one-answer clues. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I wasn't expecting to like this at all as it seems like just your standard "give your partner a clue so he can guess a word game", but this one is super clever.

The game is frustrating in a great way for the clue giver. As soon as you think you have a great clue formulated, you find some reason that your clue is a dangerous one, as it may lead your partner toward that one word that is the opponents' word, or even worse, the insta-lose card. It's very challenging to give good clues that allow your partner to get more than 2 words, but so satisfying when you pull it off!

Overall, an amazing game for this genre. While I don't love the genre, this is the best I've played in it.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is such a simple party game that in hindsight its design seems so obvious.  This is SUCH a good time.

It's clever because the entire game is in trying to come up with clues that are a bit of a stretch - if you only go for the obvious clues you'll never win, especially if you fall behind by even a single word.

That makes it seem to me like this is definitely the kind of game that's better with a group that all know each other well and can read each other a bit.

A lot of people are hailing this as a party game for people who don't like party games, but I'm not sure I agree. I suppose it depends on why you dislike them. If you just want something a bit more thoughtful, then sure, this definitely is. But as I said, the thought in the game is sort of contingent on being able to figure out people's thought processes and that sort of thing is DEFINITELY not everyone's cup of tea. I'm personally all for it, but I could see why someone wouldn't care for this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I’ve said it before, but I will say it again: Chvatil is probably the most talented and diverse game designer who has ever lived. I actually don’t care much for many of his games, although I do like some of them, and I think Uwe is the best designer ever. Still, hats off to Chvatil. This time he has designed a surprisingly simple party game which has gotten a lot of hype. I have had my eyes on it for a while, but due to the hype I went out and got it earlier than expected and paid a little more. And overall I’m glad that I did.

I’m definitely not a huge fan of this game and speak about it at every chance I get, as it seems a lot of people currently do, but I like it. It’s a deceptively simple word game in which you’re trying to get your team to guess 8 or 9 words which are placed randomly in a grid of 5 times 5 cards. 

The tension comes mainly when you’re the Spymaster and need to come up with a clever clue which allows your teammates to guess 2 or 3 answers in one shot! Also, the game is tense as you need to “outwit” your opponents, while still trying to make sure that your teammates don’t misinterpret (easier said than done…) so they don’t guess an incorrect neutral word – or, even worse, the other team’s words. Or, of course, the worst thing of all: the assassin, which makes you lose the game instantly… So far I’ve never seen this happen (in more than 10 games), but I definitely think it will happen eventually.
It works well with 4, 6 and 8 players – and also with 2, which I have greatly enjoyed as a coop with my wife!

The reason I’m not totally sold on this party game is because it’s missing a little bit to be a “party” game. It’s very intriguing, but when the spymasters sit and try to think of clever clues, and when the other team is guessing, there is basically nothing you can do and it can get a little boring… This has happened several times, and the term “boring” is obviously not something you want in a party game! Still, I think it’s a very good game. Perhaps not as innovative as some claim as the overall mechanic has been seen in older games before, but Chvatil put a different twist on it, and it is a good game overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Worthy of the hype. Codenames is a party game with a rules set of Taboo/Apples To Apples-level rules complexity that is [i]hard[/i] to play well. In fact if the game has any weaknesses, it is that it is too much of an intellectual challenge to function comfortably as a party game.

That said, I wouldn't want to play this all the time but as a design ... my hat's just off. One of those rare occasions where you just look at a game and are blown away that nobody thought of it before because it feels so incredibly obvious in retrospect.

RATING: 9
There's a lot of party games out there that are more just fun activities to get people laughing and having a good time. Most of the time we just simply play round after round not keeping score and soaking up the funny moments. I would compare Codenames with the likes of Avalon. Stay with me. A lot of these games don't have an end in sight (Wits and wagers, Telestrations, etc) but this style party game does. Once all of you agents have been discovered, the game is over an you have accomplished something. Again, we don't really keep score when playing this game but rather keep playing it after each act ends. There's a small sense of accomplishment as each games ends but then you want to go at it again. Truly a phenomenal game which lives up to the hype.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros: Easy to teach, can accommodate many players, lots of variety.

Cons: Requires a certain amount of "on the spot" creativity that some players may not enjoy, or may feel pressured by.

This is currently my favorite party game. Unique, simple, easy to teach and play, with a great amount of replayability. Searching for connections among the puzzle of relevant words is challenging, and whether you're watching your team either a) make all the same connections, validating your spy-master genius, or b) make horrifically unpredictable and hilarious connections, it is one hell of a fun time either way.

Searching for a con, I've noticed certain types of players can get flustered by the "on the spot" nature of the spymaster role. Still, if a "no-pressure" atmosphere is fostered, it's hard to imagine any group not having a fun time with this.

To part, I'll offer a brief story : We had intended to do some moderate gaming with some friends and family after a holiday shindig, but my wife's 70-year-old Aunt and Uncle decided to stay the night, who are not gamers. We swapped to party games, and the degree of hilarity that ensued with Codenames was completely unexpected. 

Any party game that can leave a group of players ranging from 20 to 70 simultaneously bent over with hysterical laughter is an absolute winner in my book.

RATING: 7.7
So, got this for Christmas and played it with my family on Christmas day. My whole family loved it. We ended up playing it 10 times. This quickly became one of my families top favorite games - and we play a lot of games as a family - some older some new. I can see this game being pulled off the shelf frequently when the family is together. 

As a side note, this game worked great with our "daughter" from El Salvador. She was able to play along with us because of the simple rules - 1 word, 1 number clue - plus the clear, clean cards. She learned some new words and participated just like our other 2 daughters. This is a great educational game for ELL students. Should be in every classroom.

RATING: 6.75
I like this game but I have to be in the right mood to want to play it. I love games that make me think a lot but this one makes me think a lot and so I am not interacting with other people because I am so focused on figuring out what clue I want to give out or just trying to decide what the clue meant. I think it is a great game and very easy for anyone to enjoy, but there is just a time and place for it and so I am not normally wanting to reach for it. Especially when I don't have as much time as I want to for games so I am prioritizing others over it. 
If you are the kind of person that likes thinking games but not as much on the strategy kind, this is for you. Or if you have a fairly sized group of people that you play with and want to involve all of them in the same game. There is a limit on how many people should be on one game because some people end up hiding in the background

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the most fun party games on the market. 2 teams compete to uncover their spies from a grid of 25 tiles (hiding spies and civilians) before the other team uncovers their spies. First team to have all of their spies uncovered wins.

I like team games as party games because half the players win each game, instead of just having 1 winner.

One Spymaster states a single word clue and a number to tjheir team (such as "bird" "2" which may be used if 2 of your spies are codenamed "Robin" and "Crow"). The word clue relates to one or more spy codenames on the grid. The number designates how many spies the clue relates to. It's easy to be very specific and use an obvious codename to help your team identify one spy, but it is tricky trying to fine a great 1 word clue that identifies 2 or more spies without steering your team to a spy on the other team.

If your team uncovers a spy from the other team, it counts for the other team.

You want to pay attention to the clues used by the other team as well, so you know which cards to avoid turning over that are likely to be the other team's spies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
w/ Deep Undercover

---
A 6 rating is high for me for a party word game. But it's still a word game. It does fill a really nice niche of being able to play with basically any number of people (minimum 4), on teams, with people collaborating. But the side that is giving the clues requires [i]a lot[/i] of thought, and can drag if not careful. Have cattle prod at the ready!

RATING: 9
Chcesz przekonać znajomych do gier planszowych, ale na widok ciężkich pudeł, dużych planszy, mnogości kart czy surowców nagle przypominają sobie o włączonym żelazku albo płaczącym dziecku? Niestety u nas część znajomych w ogóle nie daje się namówić na gry z planszą, surowcami, nawet jeśli są proste. Wtedy z pomocą przychodzą Tajniacy - szybka i prosta gra, w którą można grać w każdym przedziale wiekowym, zapewnia odrobinę zdrowej rywalizacji, kupę śmiechu i zaskoczenia, że można w ten sposób połączyć tak zupełnie różne słowa. Wytłumaczenie zasad i rozłożenie gry zajmuje 5 minut. Doskonała na imprezę, spotkanie rodzinne, do pubu, szkoły, na piknik - w każdym gronie wiekowym. Must have!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vlaada did it again. Codenames is a cooperative word game suitable for non-gamers and could even be considered a "party game" (of the "hey, that's clever" kind, not the "roaring laughter" kind). One player per team hints at a subset of 25 available terms by saying one word and the quantity of terms that are associated with it. Teams need to identify "their" words without revealing the other teams words or even encountering the dreaded Assassin, which would result in an instant loss. Plays are short but satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Could be argued as a "party game" but there's some serious thinking going on here, more than most simple "party games".

RATING: 9
This is the best party game that I've ever played. It plays well with any number of people, as long as everyone can see the cards, and I've yet to find anyone who didn't enjoy it. It requires thought and creativity, but it's easy enough that anyone can learn it in a few minutes.  It's also endlessly replayable, as the cards will come out in a different combination each and every time.  Just an awesome, awesome game!

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
[b]Brian - Christmas 2015[/b]
First played at the Visalia Gaming Group.  Knew instantly that it was a game that Patience would enjoy.  Game is played in teams.  25 cards are laid out.  The clue giver has a map of the board in front of them indicating their cards, opponent's cards, neutral cards, and the spy.  The object is to give clues to get their teammates to guess all of their cards before the other team guesses all of theirs.  The starting team always starts with one extra card to guess - done to even it out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Now I finally get the hype! This is for me one of the best party games ever. What I like most is that it's a word game for people who don't like word games. Having to come up with spelling or the like isn't necessary - this is just word association. It's very impressive to watch some of the mental gymnastics as players try to find unusual connections between words in the display.

This has a lot of replayability, and is ripe for expansions just by adding some more word cards to the mix. Love it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The problem with this game is that it depends way too much on the ability of people to play the "right" way. Spymasters are part of a team so it's only human for them to try and influence the way their teammates think. Simple nods and gestures can get people to go to a different direction making the game very prone to intentional or non-intentional manipulation. In that regard, it's quite broken. Since the game is played as a party game, the likelihood of people skirting the rules is really quite high. My rating is a reflection on how the game doesn't put into account human nature.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Nice double-sided cards providing lots of different words. Clear symbology on the key card that faces the clue-givers. A few qualms: the assassin token is unnecessary; they cards should have large-font text facing the guessers as well as the clue-givers; when I'm the guesser, I find myself reading the clue-giver-facing word upside down rather than reading the guesser-facing word; the cards should be square to make for a nice square grid.

Experience: Interesting and fun. Totally different games as the clue giver vs. guesser. As the clue giver, it's a painstaking search for patterns that involve some words, but not others. Very challenging. As a guesser, it's fun to scour the words trying to find matches, and to get inside the head of the clue giver. There are so many different ways to read into each clue, this game prompts lots of fun discussion afterward.

Unfortunately the game stifles discussion during the game, so as to not reveal anything about unguessed clues, which is unfortunate and makes for a very quiet affair. Clue givers are forced to be emotionless, lest they betray information about whether a guessed word was the intended word or not. It's unsatisfying when a game ends in assassination.

First Played: 2015-11-18
Last Played: 2017-12-05
Plays (13):
4 players: 4
5 players: 6
7 players: 2
8 players: 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game as a 2v2, especially if it is couple vs. couple.  You really have to know the other player(s) on your team to succeed.  Even then, it can lead to some absolutely hilarious mistakes as you completely misunderstand someone's clues.  That's what makes this game shine.

The best part about being a spymaster is actually the banter with the other spymaster.  Once you see what they're trying to do with their clue, you think "Wow, that's a great clue!" or "Pff, there's no way they'll get that" or "what the hell are you trying to do?"

I actually feel more connected with the opposing spymaster than I do with my own agents.

Replaced by Duet, though, as we mainly play 2p. Kept the code names pieces in the Duet box though, so the option is always there (with double the words!!)

It's less fun to be the agent, at least in my opinion, but I'm happy to play either role
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
[b]What I like:[/b] Easy to teach. Able to have people jump in and out of play. the graphic design is very clean, and the game is a lot of fun in the right group.

[b]What I dislike:[/b] playing with different experience levels and ages can be difficult.  If you don't have a shared pool of experience, it can be difficult to play at a high level, ie 3-4 targets.

[b]Colour Blindness:[/b] None. the words are very clear.

[b]Other Notes:[/b]
I have the base game as well as the Game designer Promo set.

RATING: 3
So we played 2 rounds of this, then moved on to One night ultimate werewolf.
While i found the concept interesting and we did have a few laughs during the game, it just didn't connect with us (in the way games like ONUW, Resistance, Spayfall or Dixit do).

some reasons (some relating to the game, others to the players):

1. it's VERY "thinky". Which can make the game drag while the spymaster tries to come up with good clues, or
2. the spymaster just uses "xyz 1" clues, which leads to sure points but also makes the game REALLY boring. 
3. Some layouts/words will probably just favour one team over the other (but probably just slightly or unpredictably or not at all because it depends more on what the players are thinking than on the actual words?)
4. the single word clues are incredibly restrictive. While some people may find this enhances creativity and forces people to think outside of the box, for us it felt a bit dull and counterproductive in a "party game" that should be encouraging interaction, which leads to
5. there is very little interaction...
6. I just never felt like it made much sense to try and "get inside other player's heads" the way you can in games like Dixit or Spyfall.

Overall it just wasn't a very fun experience and i don't quite understand yet what all the fuss is about.
I'll gladly give it another chance, perhaps with another group, but i'm not 100% sure this game will work for me.

I'd currently much rather play another round of Dixit, Spyfall, Resistance, ONUW or try out Mysterium....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The strength of this game seems to be that the teams who work together best are those with the most similar worldviews, since they can outline connections between concepts which would be sent and received identically.  Teams that missfire are then enouraged to learn from their peers about the topics where they fell short.  However, the spy theme feels cheap, the trivia is superficial and the components are hideous.  I just want to play anything else.  Even pictionary looks like a fresh and interesting alternative.

RATING: 7
This is a "party game" by Vlaada Chvatil, where you play in two teams and you have to guess a number of words simply by giving a one-word clue. 
Pro: You can introduce this game to non-gamers easily.
Cons: While it is a game you can play in a large group, it is not a party game. If you want to play a party game from Vlaada Chvatil, try Pictomania. That game gets people laughing easily. This, not so much. More of a cerebral game you can play in a big group.

I'm actually not sure why people rate this so highly. I wouldn't recommend this as a party game at all. It's more of a 2v2 type game in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Why do I rate Codenames a 10? Being as objective as possible, this is a flawless game design. Yes, I can understand why some people would not like this game as much as me, but you cannot argue that it is a masterpiece in game design. Codenames is as streamlined as it gets. It is both a party game and a strategy game. It plays a large group in a short amount of time, and people can jump in in the middle of a game. Virtually infinite replayability AND a low price point. It may not be my favorite game but it is a flawless game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-8

In Codenames liggen er 25 kaartjes open op tafel. Op elk kaartje staat een woord. Je speelt het spel in twee teams: het blauwe en het rode team. Elk team heeft een leider. Deze leiders zien een raster. Als je leider bent van het blauwe team, dan moet je ervoor zorgen dat jouw team alle kaartjes kan raden die overeenkomen met alle blauwe vakjes in het raster. Als je teamleden ooit het woord kiezen dat overeenkomt met het zwarte kruis, dan is je team meteen verloren. Als leider geef je een tip door een woord en een getal te zeggen, bijvoorbeeld heet 3. Dat wil zeggen dat er (minstens) 3 woorden op tafel liggen die met het woord “heet” hebben te maken. De spelers van je team proberen dan deze woorden te vinden. Elke keer als het blauwe team een woord aanduidt dat overeenkomt met een blauwe kleur op het raster, wordt er een blauwe kaart op dat woord gelegd. Het blauwe team scoort nu een punt. Bij een foute gok kan het rode team punten scoren of (nog erger) kan het team meteen verliezen (als het zwarte kruis wordt gekozen). Het team dat als eerste alle woorden in zijn eigen kleur kan raden, wint.

RATING: 10
I get why a lot of people don't like this, but everyone I've played it with loves it.

So yeah you can sometimes (often?) find yourself in a group of a dozen people all silently staring at a grid of cards of random words as the spymaster is thinking up clues, but there's a lot of fun in the challenge of being a spymaster to link as many clues as you can in a way that your team can unpack without too much risk of losing. You often have to be very creative and loose in interpretation when making clues. Then its just as much fun on the other side, having to get inside the mind of your spymaster to figure out what they meant, while arguing with your teammates about it.

RATING: 9
[2016-02-09 Rating: n.a. -> 9]
Since I like being creative with words, Codenames immediately caught me attention when I first read about it. When I had the chance to play it, I wondered why no one else came up with this idea before. Codenames feels like a classic party game that should have been around for ages. Everything is smooth and the game is a lot of fun. 

Still, I wouldn't put Codenames on the table with every group. The game is quite thinky and you need a certain amount of creativity to come up with clues as a spymaster. I've witnessed games where this became a problem and the spymaster felt kind of overwhelmed and surely didn't have a good time.

But with the right crowd, I can see myself playing Codenames for years to come. After Pictomania, the next great party game from Vlaada Chvatil!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game is great for non-gamers. It's light, easy to teach, encourages communication, gives lots of moments of laughter, and can also give some real head-scratching moments where you just look at the spymaster and can't figure out what the hell they're talking about. Everything about the game says that this should be a great time with family/friends. So why cant I seem to enjoy myself while playing it?

I think part of what stifles this game for me (personally) is just how utterly slow and tedious each turn feels. There's so much waiting to do, especially if you play with AP prone people. The game does include an optional timer to 'fix' this but it often gets people to swing too far the other way where they give 1 word clues (which is super boring for the spies) round after round until the game ends by attrition. There's also the not-so-little matter of having the spymaster keep a pokerface. Some people can do this just fine, but if your (or worse so, your opponent's) spymaster has an obvious tell, then lots of tension is removed from the game. Although not allowed by the rules it's very hard to keep people from staring down the spymaster while they decide upon clues or while you're making guesses and adjusting according to their reactions. It's even harder to keep some of the spymaster's mouths shut while they're revealing the results of a guess. I can't tell you how many times I've heard "Oh, that's not what I meant, but you guessed a word anyway". Again, this is expressly forbidden in the rules and yet its hard to fault players (especially new ones) for doing so. Which brings me to the last ding against the game... this is supposed to be a party game and yet two of your players are supposed to be nearly silent with poker faces like statues. This is completely at odds with what a party is like! On the spy side, players can joke and converse freely, but the poor spymasters are segregated from the rest of the group by this artificial wall the game puts up. It makes it difficult to really enjoy the company of others in this (ostensibly) jovial setting when you can only talk to people in one word clues and can't show any emotion.

Codenames is mechanically sound. The concepts are good and the components are wonderful, but the gameplay is just at odds with the settings that it wants to be played in. I'd still play it if someone asks for it, but ultimately it's too light for a game night and too "gamey"  for parties, so it fails to find it's niche among my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent social game, provided the "callers" for each team slide naturally into thinking in terms of concept-association, and aren't inclined to just freeze up.  Nice element of suspense and surprise, as one person's idea of an obvious and narrow clue turns out to be wide-open for interpretation, and players inch dangerously close to picking the dreaded assassin card.  Fun.

RATING: 8

A bit surprised to see it described as a "party game" as we find it quite brain wracking and more prone to quiet concentration than the hooting and hollering you might expect in a real party game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Codenames lives up to its hype. It's my new favorite large-party game, especially for 6 or more players. I've played with fewer but the game really shines with a healthy mix of teams who can chat together over what on earth the clue-giver was thinking. I'd recommend adopting house rules on what words are allowed (proper nouns, compound words, etc.) and how dire the assassin is. All told, every experience I've had with Codenames has been a good one and I look forward to many more.

Why this isn't a 10:
-> Only works with larger groups (6+)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Chvatil is frequently called an innovator and a creator of lots of unique games, but the games I've tried from him (Through the Ages, Tash-Kalar, and Codenames) have all seemed to be transplants of existing ideas into new milieus. TTA abstracted and simplified the Civilization computer series into a 4-hour competitive game, which I appreciated. Tash-Kalar added random goals, input randomness, assymetry, and Euro-style theme to an abstract, which I appreciated much less. I'd place Codenames somewhere in between the two.

Codenames takes the controlled-communication party game style of Dixit, Concept, or Catchphrase and makes them a competitive team game. This means that the system needs to be tightly controlled -every in-game action must be carefully indicated, and each "guess" has a chance to lose you the game. The communication, too, is carefully controlled; you can't use characteristics of words themselves, only the meaning, and the number you use can't be used to clue anything. The words are carefully chosen to create overlap, and potential first-player advantage is carefully avoided.

I'm sure somebody who hates party games and loves competitive ones would appreciate this game a lot. As somebody who appreciates both, I find it less successful. I don't mind the looseness and inherently variable difficulty of traditional party games, and Codenames adds very little to the competitive game -it's more about what's removed than what's added. While some concepts are neat (the assassin, the variable number of guesses, attempting to avoid opponent's clues), I don't feel the game has much to offer to somebody who gets their fill of cluegiving from party games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the best party games for a board game lite crowd. There aren't many rules to remember and every round and game is different (3.765464 x 10^66 different permutations of the board). Basically you have a 5x5 grid of words on the table, with a hidden card that shows which word is for which team per round, and each team selects one person to give clues to guess the words. 

It's cheap, usually ~$15, easy to get everyone to play, plenty of fun for all skill levels, good for traveling, and is fun to see what your team members think of and how their mind works. If you like this, you'll probably like Mysterium or Deception. If it has a downside it's that while there is variety of the word choices, there's really one one mechanic of the game and not any real strategy. Not that that's bad, but I prefer strategic games.

RATING: 6
It’s an okay party game for non-gamers since its easy for participants to pick up the rules quickly, but similar to Scrabble, I dislike games where the rules are not totally self-contained within the game itself, but rather rely on rules external to the game; in this game the rules rely on the rules and grammar of the English Language.   Like Scrabble, you need to play this game with a dictionary, Internet Web Browser, and/or Thesaurus by  your side (to avoid unwanted hostilities AFTER a clue is given).  Games like this straddle the line of feeling more like “work” and less like “fun.”  There is also the issue of Analysis Paralysis on the part of the clue-giver (is that a word?  Is that one word?  Is that a hyphenated word? Is that two words?)   
You also have to play this with an even number of players and it only works best with six or eight.  
To end on a positive note, the game play is fast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Vladda seems to have hit it out of the park again, and created the perfect-ish party game.  The design is approachable and works with most numbers of players (though even is better, and if you go beyond 8 or so, there isn't enough for each player to do).  
The game encourages creativity as well as reading your fellow players, since you not only have to connect words, but guess how others will connect them.  It can be frustrating if they don't think the same way you do, and a difference in pop culture (history, geography..) knowledge or vocabulary can also be a barrier.  As long as the players have a willingness to try, it's usually a good time.  
You only run into trouble if they aren't, and just sullenly pick words without proper deliberation.  Worse still, I've run into several problems with clue givers jumping the gun.  It seems to take a considerable amount of self-restraint to sit there and not react as players discuss possibilities and point at cards (w/out touching them).   Depending on the hour, state of inebriation, and jumpiness of personality, this may be a problem for some.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Vlaada Chvátil is on fire right now.  From gamers games to this piece of simple brilliance.  This is one of those games you think, how has no one ever thought of this before?  And now they have and the world is a better place for it.  You are simply describing words as efficiently as possible by trying to describe 2 or more words with a single word clue.  And that is it.  But it really works so well.

My family of part-time (if I am lucky) gamers has embraced Codenames and they want to play it to the exclusion of anything else.  Their enthuiasm is a rare treat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.57
This game completely justified it's position only after a month of becoming available. It truly is the best "party" game I played. And it did not surprise me since the most played party game on almost every occasion in my case is [b]Associations[/b]. A game similar to Time's Up, but requiring lots of people,  and only some pens and papers. And a stopwatch. I really love that game. Codenames scratches the same itch, giving it interesting theme and a twist. It can accommodate uneven number of people and goes really fast (with some help of a sand clock). It is the perfect game for everybody who likes playing with words, making witty associations. The ranking might go higher. The only limitation is moderate knowledge of English so not everybody in my company is comfortable with it, but only on a small margin. Otherwise great light game from crazy [b]Vlaada Chvatil[/b].

[b]Edit:[/b] Upgraded from 9 to 9.5 after 31 plays.
[b]Edit:[/b] Downgraded to 8.5 after 36 more plays.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating lowered from 7.92 to 7.73 due to the revision of components and theme+mechanics.
[b]Update:[/b] Decreased from 7.73 to 7.57 because it turned out there is finite replay value.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Huge reword for associating a lot of different words with only one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
April 2016
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This party game splits the group into 2 teams with 1 member of each team playing as the spymasters.  The rest of the team members try to guess the identity of their target agents' codenames which are randomized words on a 5x5 grid.  They are given a one-word clue along with an associated number by their spymaster.  They must avoid guessing a bystander's codename, the codename of the opposing team's targets, or the assassin.  Guessing the codename of the assassin automatically loses your team the game.

This game lived up to the hype and our group enjoyed it a LOT!  The key for the spymaster is to give a clue that is associated to the most number of their targets without possibly linking it to the other team's targets or the assassin.  It is always fun and interesting to see how your teammates think, and how they think YOU think.  The first time our group learned it, we ended up playing 8 times in a row!  Highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Codenames is a fun 4 player game which becomes more engrossing the more times I play.  I can't imagine playing it with any number other than 4.  Also, I do wonder if this would have received the same hype if it wasn't designed by Chivatal.

(Wife rating - 8.5)
(11 year old daughter rating - 9)

RATING: 9
This game is insanely popular, so I won't bother explaining the game.

The crux of the game is using word association to link as many of your words together as you can, while simultaneously trying to avoid opponents words and the auto-lose word.

It's pretty quick and I challenge you to play it once and then put it away. This game is fantastic and works well with just about everyone. It's not a hilarious party game. In fact, it's pretty quiet, thoughtful, and rewards cleverness. That suits me just fine.

RATING: 10
I thought I would like this when I first read the rules. The first time i got to play this, we played I'm not sure how many game for 8 hours straight. Then we played some more the next day. The game is awesome and addictive. It plays so fast, normally. This and Time's Up are my top 2 party games. It's fun playing on both sides. 

The only issues is sometimes certain set ups are just way lopsided, but again the game is fast enough it doesn't matter for long. Playing with dumb people also makes the game significantly less fun, because its teams and you never want to be on the team with someone unable to communicate effectively.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I must admit to being sceptical of all the hype going into this game but I have to say, for such a simple idea the Codenames delivers.

25 words in a grid, give one-word clues to your team to guess your teams words and not those of the opposition.  One of the 25 words instantly causes either team to fail the game.  That's about as complex as the game is.  The real game is finding the right clues and how creative/abstract/tenuous you can be to make them to check off as many words as possible.

A caveat must be made, that this game is ultimately made exponentially better depending on the people you play it with; with the wrong people Codenames would have the potential to be very dry, but that is the way with most party games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I love, love, love:
- the easy-to-learn rules and quick gameplay
- the after-game discussions/arguments about why certain clues were used

I dislike:
- that the game is almost... too simple?

Final verdict: A good game that plays quickly and simply and gets your brain thinking in a less number- and engine-focused way (unlike many of the Euros I own).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game! Family favorite. (My family is 8 total, ages 23+)
We play that you can only use 1 word no matter what. It takes away the subjectiveness and puts everyone on the same playing field. 
One thing that pulls back from the game being a 10 is the fact that the game isn't 100% fair... 1 team could have 5 words that are all animals, and the other team could have none that go together at all. That's the only problem with it. But that's not fixable. 
It's still fantastic, and for a family who fights a lot during games, we didn't fight during this one. Everyone had a blast. Highly recommend (especially if you love problem solving, words, and stretching the way you think).

This game is TOTALLY different with children/anyone under 20 years old.
They think differently. Way differently. I mean.... WAAAAYYYYY.....
It is frustrating to get a clue "scientist 2" and the answers being "experiment" and "eye"... and you ask WHAT?! And he says, "Scientists can do experiments on eyes." As frustrating as it is, it is SO MUCH FUN! It makes the game great when someone who is "bad" does the clue giving. You have to think how they think. Clue is "Pen"... ok... "Ball" and "Point". Yep. Clever girl.

So, whether you're middle school, high school, college, post college, or all of the above, you will enjoy playing this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
[2016 February 26; 21 plays; 7/10]
I've been really enjoying this game! I'm inclined to rate it an 8/10 because of how much I enjoy the game when I play, but there are a lot of factors which prevent me from playing this one more:
* It's a short game with shallow strategy.
* The game does not provoke the loudness I expect from a party game. It supports a high player count, but it's like they forgot to design whatever elements of joviality they could into the game.

For now, I'll conservatively rate this as a 7/10, presuming that once the CotN feeling wears down I'll at least begin to grow tired of it.
