RATING: 8
Very interesting word association/deduction game. It is really not a party game. For that it is too much silence. I like the challenge of finding words that can be associated with a least 3 words on the table, and at the same time should not be associated with any of the others. It is really difficult. A great idea, which could have some down time playing with "wrong" people.
The problem with this game is that you really should think a lot to come up with the perfect word. At the same time, a lot of thinking makes it boring for other players. So...

Edit: I had a much better experience with it the second time I played it. Really good atmosphere around the table, so I increased the rating a little.

I don't know if Codenames will reach the nearly hundred plays I've gotten out of ONUW and Daybreak, but it wouldn't surprise me if it did.  I am generally not a fan of Vlaada Chvatil's designs, but he absolutely knocked this one out of the park.

RATING: 8
This is a great word/guessing game, reminiscent of Taboo.  Ideal number of players is 4 so you don't have to deal with guess by committee.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Codenames is SUPER fun as a small party game.  The only thing is that there's two teams, with one person on each team giving the "codes".  These codes are precisely one word long.  The code givers, thus, have to be able to keep a straight face, not flap their arms excitedly or when someone is close to guessing right or groan when someone is close to guessing wrong.  You'll need a genuine poker face or you'll ruin it.  But don't let this deter you.

I highly recommend this game.  I buy a small amount (20 dollars or so worth) of things off Amazon each month, and this is at the top of the list for next month)

RATING: 7.5

I've played the game in settings ranging from mid-day, sober competitions to 2am drunk plays (both examples including teaching new people), and it's worked well.

The theme doesn't work at all for me, but that doesn't bother me here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
CGE hat sich in den letzten Jahren als mutiger Spielkamerad gezeigt: ungewöhnliche Themen (LETZTE WILLE, 20. JAHRHUNDERT) und innovative Spielideen (GALAXY TRUCKER,  TZOLKIEN) bishin zur Integration von Cyberspace (ALCHEMIST). Und nun also der Partytexter CODENAMES, das dich nahtlos in die Reihe fügt. CODENAMES ist eine simple, kreative Idee, in der es für einen Teamchef darum geht Überbegriffe zu finden, die möglichst viele Wörter subsumieren, die wiederum durch das Team in einer Auswahl von ausliegenden Hauptwörtern erraten werden sollen. Wie bei allen Partygames lebt auch CODENAMES vom Interaktion und Interpretation. CODENAMES wäre in seiner Einfachheit wirklich gut, wenn da nicht die vermaledeite Dehnbarkeit von Begrifflichkeiten wäre. Da werden grenzwertige Substantivierungen und Neologismen in den Raum geworfen, die das Spiel für meinen Geschmack aushebeln. Beispiel: Wenn zwei Wörter wie "Schimmel" oder "Uhr" erraten werden sollen, wird vom Spielkapitän kurzerhand das Wort "Pferdezeit" in den Raum geworfen. Wenn sich die Spielrunde in der Zusammensetzung von Synonymen genügt, wird CODENAMES nicht besser als jedes Kreuzworträtsel. Dummerweise unterstützt die Regel solch einfallslose Wortbildungen, so dass es letztlich in der Hand der Spieler liegt, aus CODENAMES das zu machen, das es verdient zu sein.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Still have trouble calling this a "Party" game. However, It still has a place in my collection. I would pair this with Dixit, for a more subdued gathering. I also enjoyed this as a 2 player experience. Very casual co-op . My hubby and I played this over coffee on a Sunday morning...perfect!! Overall, I would pull this out for a quick filler between 2 bigger games.

RATING: 7
I'm glad I got to try this out.  Vlaada Chvatil is not the type of designer who I'm usually seeking out. I find his games too complex for their own good. But I recognize his brilliance for being a left-field designer. So I was intrigued by This simple card game designed by someone who is clearly a master of his craft.  Turns out this is such a simple, excellent idea - and well executed.  While it may be easy for the "Spymaster" to give a clue to one card, finding similarities between multiple cards and then giving one clue word to hint at two or more... very smart!  This is a good game for fans of word games, Dixit, or nifty party games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

- works well as a 2 players game
- very focused on interaction between players
- can be quite fun and very rewarding when you get to connect with your partner.
- risk and reward
- fast and furious
- superb value for money

Cons:
- limited number of cards meaning after you've been through them all once, it is tempting to use references to previous plays, which isn't cheating (and doesn't feel like cheating), but is certainly not as rewarding
- I can see ourselves losing some interest for it quite soon.

RATING: 5.5
Art & Production - :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Theme & Narrative - :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Mechanic Elegance - :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability & Fun - :star::star::star::star::nostar:
X-Factor/Originality- :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

Overall: 14.5/25

A game that is too reliant on the people who play it. Arguably this could be said for all party games but here i feel it is more acute: with a tactical or unflamboyant group this can become nothing more than mundane as each team turtles forward with 1/2 guesses per turn. Furthermore, with any more than 6 players I feel one or two players can become overly pushed aside.

Having said that, add a few drinks and some in-jokes and it can take flight.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Such a simple idea converted in to an absolutely fantastic party game! Everyone I've played this with, winds up walking away saying, "wow that was a really fun game! How much was it?" Vlaada really nailed this one.
It's a word deduction game. You have a 5x5 grid of cards. There are two teams competing to guess who their spies are. To win, one team must outguess the other and identify 8 cards (or 9 if you go first). They do this, because one member of the team per round is designated as a spymaster who sees where on the grid the spies are located. There are tons of double sided word cards, and a stack of symmetrical grid cards that can be rotated on any of 4 sides. This allows for a LOT of randomization and replayability. Everyone stays engaged, the spymasters: by coming up with clues linking words so the rest of their team can guess more than one at a time, and the team members trying to figure out whats going on in the spymasters head.
A game well deserving of praise!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A very fun deduction party game! Teams of players try to guess the cards with the codenames from their agents before the other team is able to guess theirs.

Weight: family

Length: 30 mins
Opinion: I like the idea of the game, you can think this is a party game, and this is not my opinion. This is a family game, but do not go for a party with this one. First of all, this is one of those games you have to be flexible with how you play, do not cheat saying clues, but do not stubborn either.
Choosing the clues to give to your team is a hard time, trying to find out which ones your Captain have said is the funniest part

RATING: 9
First few plays had far more "aha!" moments than one might expect from a party game. Gets to some of the multi-layer deductions that Hanabi has ("I wonder if she gave that clue because she was hoping that I'd realize she was choosing not to give this OTHER clue, in which case...") without the need for Hanabi's pre-agreed conventions. Plus, the creativity involved in picking words is more appealing to me than Hanabi.

(Vlaada is a genius.)

RATING: 7
Solid team-based party game.  Plays quick with extremely easy rules.  Often leads to unintentional, though enjoyable, humor. 

Occasionally lets you put those inside-jokes to use, allowing the association of a cluster of words in an awkward way that no one but you and your spouse/brother/best friend teammate could. Suddenly making you both feel like geniuses, all because you both once saw an obese man in short-shorts at a bbq, and it allowed your partner to guess "Lemon" and "smuggler" off of your clue of "Ben".

Personal experiences may vary.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Simple party game of word association played in teams. One player is supposed to give clues on his team's words, but it's usually very hard to link more than two words with one clue (luck of the draw can be decisive here). And if his team is winning, it's easier to go for an obvious clue for a single word, which makes the game boring. I played it three times in a row, but even with totally different words, the game already felt repetitive by the end. It's a less fun "Dixit" or "Pictionary" without much room for creativity. It's unbelievable how this is in the top 20 games here on BGG and won the Spiel des Jahres. but it certainly has a lot to do with having been designed by Vlaada.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2-8 Players

RATING: 9
This might honestly just be the best party game, period. This game is chock-full of creativity, tension, teamwork, comebacks, laughter, and excitement. It's extremely easy to grasp, plays up to 8 or even more very well, rewards good players while simultaneously allowing weaker players to catch up, and is about as far from "solvable" as could be. The sheer variety of combinations and the ways the clues can be given is simply stunning. I want to play it right now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Codenames is a party game for folks who don't like party games. By this, I mean that it eschews the usual creative, artistic vibe of many party games such as Charades and Pictionary (amongst others) and aims for a game of logic, semantics, and semiotics. In short, its a game of communicating the location of spies by giving one word and one number. For example, Shoe-2 might be given to help you locate agents Foot and Walker, but maybe enemy agent Shoestring is out and about too (hence, perhaps the 2 was to signal that *only* two of three shoe-related words are of the team). Great for folks who love solving and generating mini-logic problems and can be a hoot. The addition of an assassin which makes your team lose instantly can also make for funny game endings.

I'm looking forward to playing the "Dixit: Dream Detective" variant of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent party game for 4+ players (there are alternate rules for 2 or 3 player games, but it really shines with 6+ players). A rare game in that it doesn't seem to have an upper limit on how many people can successfully play. Game length doesn't vary much even with large player counts, it is always around 20-30 minutes. It encourags interaction between players, players on teams can come and go as needed without affecting game play much, and it can be played lightly off the cuff or with a deeper strategy if desired therefore appealing to a wide range of players. We like to rotate who the spymaster is each game to keep things interesting. Everyone we have played this with loves it, and they all want to play it again. The only minor criticism I have is that the theme is just tacked on and is not really part of the game at all, but it really doesn't matter as the game is so fun to play that it doesn't really require a theme to succeed.

Ahora entiendo porque quedó calificado como #1 en juegos de fiesta. Es sencillo de jugar y explicar, así como de prepararlo. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are low-level wetwork operatives who have only moments to locate and liquidate targets based on nothing more than a single word and a number.  Success means the right doors are kicked, the right throats cut, the right cars bombed.  Failure usually means two silenced shots into a dude who was just mowing his lawn, and then going back for the wife after a brief argument in the van.  But beware—your team is being stalked by a legendary rogue wetboy—and he's got claymores duct-taped to the door of his decoy apartment...

Though the team is supposed to confer, come to a consensus, and then—[i]and only then[/i]—reach out to touch the agreed-upon cards to execute the contract, there are a shocking number of unprofessional "Here, hold my hotdog—" moments where a single agent will suddenly bolt from the food court, sprint up the escalator, shoot three people on the mezzanine level, and then saunter back to take their hotdog out of your stunned hand with an honestly unperturbed "What?"

The winning team will be responsible for their own individual exfils to safehouses of their choice; the losing team will spend the last thirty minutes of their lives jogging down the street with assault rifles and body armor before being "retired" by ex-DEVGRU CIA paramilitary dressed as local SWAT.

[imageid=3354962 original]
[size=7]Fig. 1 —[i] No prior military.  No field ops.  No chance.[/i][/size]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I upgraded this from 8.3 after a few more group plays. 
this is a great game for lots of people, I think 5 is the minimum.  I had a chance to play this several times with mixed friends and with family of various ages.  It went over well with everyone.  Even for the younger (teen) kids who I thought would poo-poo this away, really got into this one.  I did finally play with my regular gaming buddies and I was surprised they all took to it after just a few minutes.  Its a great, simple concept and one that, if not already, will certainly be mimicked soon enough.  We did play with an odd number of people wherein that person played on both teams.  It worked really well.  The hardest part is watching what you say.  Even casual conversation about the words in play and guesses made can put ideas into the spymaster's head.  I really reccomend this one.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We must be approaching two dozen plays by now, and I still love this game as much (or more!) as I did on day one.

The time constraint, the passive (passive aggressive?) interaction, the liquid win/loss state, the brain burn of making increasingly tenuous connections, and the omnipresent threat of the assassin... what a game!

I don't always bring it to the table, but I think that's for the best. Instead, I prefer to savour it in the ideal conditions.

RATING: 5
It's password with a twist...I guess. Ranked fairly high for what it is. The game is functionally solid and works for most groups, but it just doesn't really feel like a game, but more so an activity. The game can either be a fast play or take a long time, while you and the other clue giver struggle finding one-word clues for their teams. 

Like I said it's not horrible and I will more than likely play it than not, but I think it's quite overrated for what it is.  It doesn't help there are Codenames-snobs that turn their noses to funner, much better party games, but say this is the magnum opus for social gatherings. Codenames, honestly, is not as fun as people make it out to be. It is highly over-rated for what it is, plain and simple. However, I can see the minimal fun in the game, and enjoy it, with the right "NON Snobby/AP-prone people. I would  still like to give Codenames: Pictures a go since it looks a lot better than just staring at words

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A team-based word game that people who normally don't like word games (or party games!) might actually still enjoy. Can have some downtime while the clue-giver tries to think of a clue that will allow their teammate to guess multiple words on their list, but still a nice game.

This game has gotten a lot of play during lunch hour. Interestingly, we have played so the two codemasters are the ones proficient in English, while the rest of the players, English is their second language. Before the game they ask about any words that they do not know the meaning of and we talk about them.

The game is highly portable (see files section for my travel size tuckbox) for lunch outings.

可以訓練團隊默契。
我少數會收藏的派對類桌遊。


繁體中文版（機密代號）
Traditional Chinese Version

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a word driven party game ideally designed for 6 or more players.  Its designed by one of the great game designers of our generation.  I believe it draws more excitement than it should simply because of the greatness of the designer.  There is a little bit interesting going on, but the game does not have a lot of novel elements even for a party game.  On the plus side: its simple, stream-lined, and the connectivity of the cards are well thought out to maximize the challenges of avoiding ambiguity.  A solid party game, but it doesnt do enough for me to rate as a top 100 game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This has got to be the most boring game I've played in a long time. I have no idea why this is so popular. I seriously have lost respect for BGG's rating system and the masses ability to pick good games after seeing how popular this is.

What is so appealing? You sit there and think of connections between your cards... I don't get any sort of excitement when someone guesses my cards correctly and I have ZERO sense of achievement when I guess the right cards. Not to mention it only takes 1 person with an IQ less than 100 to ruin the entire game. Why? Because they will give horrible connections, will take forever doing it, and always guess the wrong cards. One game I was on the stupid person's team and then the very next game (with an entirely different group of people) I watched as the stupid person ruined the game for my opponents. When that happens, there is no fun. You know you're going to win and that's BORING!

I give it a 1, not because it defies game description, but because everyone's hype about this game is broken and defies the game description.

I'm sorry BBG and BGG followers, but today you are the biggest morons.  Unfortunately, today you have superseded my expectations.

Still love Vlaada's work. One bad game doesn't define a designer.

RATING: 10
A title wholly dependent on the people you play with. Potentially a fun and challenging game of asymmetric deduction where one player offers a clue and the other matches it. edit 3/1/2017: Original score 4/10.

Codenames has become a 10/10 party game. It really does depend on the people you play with and I've ended up in a string of perfect matches.

RATING: 8
bij Pascal, 29/12/2015. Spel in twee teams (rood en blauw) rond een variabel raster van 5x5 woorden. Via een klein kaartje weten de tipgevers welke woorden rood, blauw of neutraal zijn. Er is ook een zwart woord, dat absoluut niet mag aangeduid worden of het spel is onmiddellijk verloren.  De ene speler geeft tips aan de hand van 1 woord en een getal (het aantal te vinden woorden bij die tip); de andere moet aan de hand van de tip de juiste woorden proberen aanduiden. Tof partyspel; geweldig in zijn eenvoud!

14/08/2016 Cadeau gegeven aan Grootmoe voor haar 66e verjaardag (Sleepgames 17 EUR).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very fun very light game from Master Vlada.  An array of words are placed on the board.  The players divide into two teams and each team has a codemaster.  The two codemasters have a secret chart that indicates which words belong to which team or are neutral or trigger the deadly assassin.  Each in turn gives their team a clue and a number indicating how many of the words it applies to.  So for example if the codemaster wants them to pick "snow" and "hospital" he might say "hypothermia".  Different people can have very different associations with these words so fun ensues as the team tries to figure out these cryptic clues.  Each game is maybe fifteen minutes so you'll often do multiple rounds.  It makes a great filler and also as an intro to brainier games for newbies to boardgaming.  It appeals to both party gamers and board gamers as it is easy to understand but requires real thought.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a great co-operative game for groups of 4-8.  Quick to set up and tear down.  Good tension.  Needs the right group, obviously - pairing spouses with each other can be unfair, and someone who is win-at-all-costs and will use facial expressions, gestures, etc. can ruin the spirit...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Codenames is one of the best party games on the market, especially for non-gamers. The rules are fairly simple (though there can be some debate regarding legal clues) and there is plenty of variety and challenge in mastering the ability to give and decipher clues to the word puzzle at its core. While the game's pace allows it to be played in a casual, laid-back atmosphere, that same slow pace can also make the game drag (and make me a little less interested in suggesting it). Despite that, Codenames accomplishes its goal by being an accessible party game that everyone can enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting word game. Each clue-giver gives one-word clues to his teammate(s) to get them to guess which words on a grid belong to their team. Some of the words are neutral, not so bad when you miss, but one word results in insta-loss if it gets picked. So try to tie together seemingly unrelated words while not matching words on the grid that aren't yours. Update: This game is like potato chips. I don't necessarily want a bunch of chips, but next thing I know I've eaten half the bag.

Components: Excellent - cleverly put together to avoid repetitiveness & easy setup for your 2nd game.
Replayability: if you've got at least 6+ players this is one you'll always consider, especially if you've got newbs in the mix.
Rulebook: Good Enough.

RATING: 7
Fun party/filler game. One person takes on the role of the spy master where they know who the spies working on their side are and the others take on the roles of spies trying to meet the correct contacts by their codenames.

Only thing I wish was that it was a bit easier to read the grid on the small card. It can be tough at times seeing as the grid has to be shared between 2 people and its size can make it easy to make a mistake when trying to find out what your agents codenames are.

Can depend on the group you're with as to how to tailor your clues but that's the fun of the game.

RATING: 8
2015-08-31

Initial Rating: 6.0 (August 2015)

Vlaada Chvátil is a great and diverse designer. I have still to play one of his games which I didn’t like on some level and I always buy his games. Having said that, I was expecting more from Codenames, however the jury is still out on this one as I only played it once and very quickly.

The rules are very easy to learn but the gameplay is intriguing and I like playing on teams. It seems the clue-givers have the most fun. I’m not sure how the two player version would work.

The language can be a problem with Codenames, perhaps I will get the Spanish version when it comes out.

Bottom line, I already bought a copy and I plan to play it again soon. It seems it is very group dependent but for now I feel it is a solid design.

Current Rating: 6.0
[hr]
2015-11-30

After 20+ more plays, I´m tremendously enjoying Codenames. It´s a very clever party game and I won’t refuse a game. To properly enjoy it  you need the correct game group, that was the reason I first didn’t like it very much. It has the potential of going up in my personal ratings.

Great party game, perhaps the best of the year.

Current Rating: 7.0

In English many words can mean many things while in my language the words have many less meanings, so the game is much more limited.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game and it's simplicity means a low entry barrier for none gamers. It also functions quite well as a get to know you game. Codenames has a very unique playstyle that i've not seen in other party games. However, due to the communication barriers that the game requires (codemasters and codebreakers don't speak to one another), i find it's a game i end up only playing with other games in a group of 4 rather than as the party game it was designed to be. There also seems to be a bit of diminishing returns with large groups, the more players you have the less fun and challenging it becomes as many players don't get a chance to answer and end up distracting others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.3
This game got so much hype, yet it didn't look that interesting on any of the run throughs I saw. Then I had had a chance to play it and had to run out and buy a copy, take it home, and play it again and again. 
It's quick and easy to explain we always play at least 4 games of it every time we get it out. Best with more people (several couples). Although it can be played with as few as two; I don't like it as much less than 4. 
Kids are really good at this game, surprisingly so, but only at guessing. My kids did so well guessing I mistakenly gave in to there requests to be the code mastor (one needed for each team). Kids can not be code masters!!!! But I would take any kid to help me guess. 
I highly recommend this game!!!

RATING: 8
Codenames is easily the most enjoyable word game I have played. Layers of strategy and decisions whether you are giving clues or guessing. Do you play it safe for the sure thing or try to string together multiple words to gain a slight edge? Do you risk an extra guess if you fall behind? The presence of an assassin card each round adds a great element of suspense. Extremely enjoyable and instantly addictive. An instant classic!

RATING: 10
I'm not a big fan of very light games and I'm not a fan of word games at all. Despite that I think codenames is a fantastic game. The word element is not in creating words from a pool of letters (which I loath) but making clever associations between words. It's really more of a vocabulary game, and I find that challenge very engaging and fun.

The game creates a lot of fun moments and it's interesting to hear what associations people were trying to create when the game is over.

RATING: 7
Codenames is a good solid game that will easily hold a place in my curated collection for a very long time. But I have to say it strikes me as a bit out of place that it ranks so very high on BGG relative to other party games. I suspect geeks are rating it highly for being a difficult game that rewards skillful play - as opposed to most party games where scoring is largely an afterthought and any skills required are of a very 'soft' sort. Where Codenames is not as strong as many party games (my initial impression at least) is in the unscientific Fun Factor.

RATING: 8
3-5 plays.

Codenames is a word game with some elements of strategy.  So, don't expect much depth. 

Instead, Codenames is a great alternative to more tedious party games like Catch Phrase or *shudder* Apples to Apples. It is slightly deep than this games, as one must decide how specific to make clues or how many guesses to allow that will allow their team good odds of catching up.

The fact that the game can be played within 2 minutes of explanation or by watching it makes Codenames extremely accessible.  It is quick (
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

See potential to turn this into a game I can use in my work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Enjoyable and quick party game. Out of 25 tiles each containing an ambiguous words, the explainer of each of the two groups has to lead his group to detecting the 9 (first group) respectively 8 tiles associated with his group (supposedly "agents"). To achieve this, he's only allowed to give a hint consisting of a single word and the number of tiles described by this, no further hints allowed. The group then points to the tiles they think are their agents. The challenge are associations of certain words, the explainer missed noticing. The result is a fun puzzle, especially for the explainer. Each game is quick enough to give each player the chance to prove his wording skills.

One minor niggle depending on the group: The German language might not be best suited for the game principle as the nearly unlimited possibility of our language to form composite words can lead to discussions what is still acceptable as a single word. Glasdeponie?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very funny social/party game. Better with 6 I guess.

RATING: 10
This is a fantastic game. I've played this with a number of friends that aren't board gamers and they've all loved it.

One time that I was giving the very first clue of the game, said "office 3", my team guessed "post" and "chair" correctly before guessing "light". Luckily for me that was one of my words, just not one I wanted trying to have them guess. They then proceeded to realise that "server" was on the board, and that I probably meant that, so used the bonus guess to grab four correct words on the very first go!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First off, it was only 15 USD when I bought it. And I must say, that's a fantastic price for such a well-designed game!

My favorite thing about this game is the theme. I'm a huge fan of the James Bond franchise, and this gave me a chance to show my friends my spy skills! :)

The game's mechanics are simple and nothing revolutionary, but very solid nevertheless. The box says the game is best with 6 players, but I've gotten the most enjoyment out of the 2-player cooperative rule variant. The base game is best with 4, 6, 8, or any higher even number of players. Generally speaking, 6 is the best!

All the materials that come with the game are high quality pieces (minus the hourglass, which I would never use anyways). Overall, solid game - it's my favorite party game to play for sure!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Originally only played with 4 players (two different groups). It was ok, but not the end-all, life-changing experience everyone makes it out to be.  It was fun, I'm just not sure why it's the hottest game around and "the best party game ever." Concept allows for more creativity and laugh out loud "party game" moments once you dump the instructions.  Codenames is easy and cheap so I'm not a hater, I've already got my money's worth, but I don't love it. Played it again at a higher player count after my original comments and it is definitely better, but still not a favorite and still feel it's over-rated.  Everyone seems to enjoy it though, so I'll keep it because it at the least offers an option at higher player counts and is easy to teach.

RATING: 9.5
After a second, much longer play through this is a game that I can't ever see getting old or repetitive.

This is completely accessible for non-gamers, young and old.  Quick play, easy to learn, easy to teach and players can drop in and out between rounds. 

A perfect gateway game, but so tense and interesting my gamer friends continue to request it.

Smash hit.  I think this will be an evergreen for Vlaada Chvátil.  

Update: This was my 2015 game of the year, no matter what kind of group I have when I put this on the table, everyone loves it.

RATING: 8
Believe the hype.  I was honestly baffled when I first read all the rave reviews.  The game sounded so simple, and pretty similar to other, um, less than stellar party game staples of yore (Taboo, et al.).  And while both of those things are true, it has proven to be a big hit with both my gamer friends and casual players.  A perfect filler that you can play when waiting for other people to arrive (since they can always jump right in when they do get there).  Easy to explain, tricky to play well.  A must for any game collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love and hate this game at the same time. I love it because the concept is clever, it creates some tense moments especially in late game and you can find some really clever ways to combine words. I hate it because the start can't be more boring. 2 people stare at the table and everyone sits silently waiting for clues. After the first game the cards are turned to the other side and the game is played again so it definitely has the staying power and fun factor. As I said the only thing negative with the game is its start.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Fun party game that doesn't quite live up to all the hype.  I'm willing to play if others want to but I think I will always prefer to play something else.  I hope I don't have to play this too often.

Best with six; okay with seven or eight.  Higher player counts just lead to longer turns as more players discuss options and stand up to more easily see all the words.

Four and five could be okay but they start to remove the discussion aspect of the decisions and the odd player starts to cause a problem.  Could work for two but you would have to remove the competition to win out and just treat it as a fun activity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The concept here of making connections between deliberately ambiguous words makes for a distinctive game experience, so with the right players - generally those who heckle and discuss vigorously - it can be great.
I'd hesitate to recommend it unreservedly though, as it falls quite flat with the wrong players. In particular, the spymaster needs to be willing to be reckless, both giving clues quickly (even if they might be bad clues), and avoiding the temptation to give clues that only target a single agent - guaranteeing certainty but boredom. Both of these things take the fun out of the game very quickly.
So: fun with the right crowd, but the best party games tend to nudge the players towards playing in the right spirit, and because it doesn't do so, Codenames can be risky to pull out with a new group. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vélemény: https://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/52962/tarsasjatek-fedonevek-codenames

[youtube=9ibtUlvcyiY]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A neat exercise in competitive taxonomy, like Edward de Bono's old exercise of taking eight random words and grouping them into two fours. Very elegantly gamified. Some of the feeling of Only Connect's connecting wall, or a good cryptic crossword, but always second-guessing your luck-pushing friends instead of an unknowable question-setter. Two-player is more like a single-player puzzle for the spymaster, with the solver being the voice of reason, but is still a fun exercise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8

It is a truly great game, we played it with a 91 year old this Christmas and even she fully participated and enjoyed it.
Good repeat playability, thought provoking and frankly just plain fun.
With a 20 minute playing time per game..its a 'play anywhere' kind of game.
Thank you CGE.

RATING: 7.6
Played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We aren't ones that are fond of many "Party Games" so it's probably no surprise that the party game designed for people who aren't fans of party games is a game that would appeal to us.  I also personally probably despise word games more than another other type of game.  For those reasons Codenames is a nice fit for my game collection.  Deduction is something I've grown to like, having avoided a lot of those in the past, as our son LOVES deduction games.  As the spymaster it does often seem hard to come up with clues that encompass 3+ cards well.  I suppose that is the point of it.  Those guessing can still do alright if they can recall previous clues and use their "one extra guess" to make up in later turns for failed guesses on previous ones.  We've played the game quite a bit with just 2 & 3 players and don't find it affects our enjoyment of the game much since it's a more serious game to begin with.  In fact, at 2 or 3 players it probably shouldn't qualify as a party game at all.  Another reason to like it.

RATING: 7.8
A game with many different levels, easy to pickup and teach.  Roughly 10 min to explain to new people, roughly 2 games/rounds required for new people to pick it up.  The game seems simple, and can be played simple, or it can be quite complex with your ability to win tied with how well you know or can convey an idea with one single word. Perfect for people who love word games, this is a game that can be played at any setting.  Works with family night, parties, or Mom's basement DnD night. You do need at least 4 however for it to play in its true form.

RATING: 9
Must-have for party game collections.  Hits a lot of the right notes for a small to medium group of people, gamers or not-gamers - team competition, word association, simple play with a lot of depth to the effort to deduce what your team-mate is suggesting.  The theme is pasted on but in this case it totally works - there aren't many other themes that would work well here.  Artwork on the components is outstanding (looks a lot like the artwork for Archer, which is apropos I suppose) and the components are solid, will last a long time.  Buy it.

RATING: 8
Excellent party game, hands down. There's virtually no downtime because, even if it isn't your turn, you still want to try to guess what the other team has to pick, so as to narrow your choices down. It's also a deduction game that doesn't break when mixing experienced players with newbies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Codenames:[/b][/size]
+ I like how the deduction aspect of the game is quite low. The game is more of a word game that is revolved around connecting different words.
+ I like how the memory aspect of the game is quite low. I find recalling past clues easy. 
+ The game is easy to teach
+ The game is short
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win
+ There is high replayability, especially if you combine the good sets together for more words. 

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Codenames:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the two player variant for the game. The given issue is fixed by the expansion Codenames Duet. 

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Codenames:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the downtime from waiting for the other team to finish and waiting for your team members to do their action. I prefer Codenames Duet

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Keep & Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 5

Also, you must enforce the timer rule so that the turns dont become very long. At 6 and above, the teams are able to discuss the codes with each other, which really livens the game up.

                 Too easy for SpyMasters to make a mistake (thinking a red card is one s/he should give a clue for when it should be a blue card - happened several times over several games).
                 Perhaps board should spin.

RATING: N/A
In Codenames, two teams compete to see who can make contact with all of their agents first. Spymasters give one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team. And everyone wants to avoid the assassin.

Fantastic game with a [url=https://www.etsy.com/listing/384925736/game-organizer-for-codenames?ga_order=most_relevant&ga_search_type=all&ga_view_type=gallery&ga_search_query=codename%20organizer&ref=sr_gallery_1]sweet game organizer[/url].

RATING: 8
It's been years since I've played a new Chvátil game that I really liked. Dungeon Petz was mediocre compared to Dungeon Lords (best of 2009); Mage Knight is just not for me; I played Tash-Kalar only 4-player which is probably not how it should be played but still didn't feel like I'd like to replay it.

And now here it is, a party game... And I love it. It's unique, it's great: as my wife said it's like Battleship meets Taboo and I quite like this definition even if it does not describe the best part of the game - coming up with clues for several cards at the same time, while avoiding some other cards. And this is how a communications game also becomes a brain-burner: even if it might result in some long thinking periods (of course the sandtimer helps somewhat), it's so unique and new that it deserved its Spiel des Jahres just as much as it deserves its first place in my 2015 list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a good party game, though a notch down from the very best. 

4-6 players is the sweet spot for this one, with both providing a different slant to the experience.

With four it is a tight and somewhat tense battle of wits, while 6 players opens up some of the humor and social dynamics through intra-team discussion.

It is the kind of game that once you start you can easily end up spending the rest of the night on it, playing game after game. There are few games that can do this and still be as enjoyable in the last game as the first, but this is one of them.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
One of the best parties games ever. A fantastic word game that's easy to learn and good with groups. Really the gold standard for party games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another party game that I think works better as a computer game due to what people say easily giving away extra information (though since the rules say only one word it's not as easy to game as say Dixit), but despite this being a word guessing game this is a most excellently designed game of the genre, and while party games are far from my favorite board game category I understand why this game has risen so quickly. There is a great challenge balancing giving specific clues but having a lower ceiling of number of correct answers in one turn and a high number of guesses but having to give vague clues in order to apply to more phrases. You could also purposefully lie on the number of words matching a clue to try to get more guesses (or say 0 to get infinite). As the spymaster it's also fun to watch your team come haphazardly close to guessing the instant lose word or as the opposing team attempt to goad your team to choose a word that is clearly not related to your clue, but is also a word they need to eventually guess. You need to consider choosing your clues based on the non spymasters' discussion, either so your team doesn't choose a word due to a misinterpretation of a previous clue, or by timing which clues you give when so that if the opposition is on the cusp of guessing one of your words for you, you choose to give clues to alternate words first to your team. 

Despite the game having teams 7 players worked pretty well (although unless there is a variant 5 would be weird since you would have no one to deliberate with), and having a little more than 8 would probably be fine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Gift

RATING: 8.8

RATING: 7.8
Fun casual team game.  It's hard for me to truly classify this as a "party game" because it is someways anti-party.  You do not want to be playing this with loud people in the vicinity.  Most rewarding features are giving that perfect clue as clue-master.  Can take a long time for clue-master to give clues due to the number of factors they must take in.  People who do not like long down-times may find fault with this game.  My group seems to like this more than I do, but I'm almost always open to play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We love word games of various types, so as soon as I heard about this game I knew we would love it. And it has been a huge hit in our group, from non-gamers to the hard core (who admittedly are also fans of words, word play and cryptic puzzles). Trying to clue someone to get the words you want them to get while not picking the other words is often agonizing, that perfect clue is there if you could just think of it! The words in there are clever, multiple meanings to give many possibilities and many possibilities for misinterpretation too. The added tension of the death word just to spice things up even more is a brilliant accent on a very cleverly designed game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Super fun game that works for all crowds and ages. Perfect for 4+ people, and great for ruining relationships (BECAUSE NOBODY GUESSES "CELL" OVER "HERO" WHEN THE CLUE IS "SUPER" YOU MORON, AND FOR GOD'S SAKE "HERO" IS THE ASSASSIN WORD WHAT WERE YOU THINKING)

Ahem, anyways. Infinitely replayable, super portable (perfect to bring to kill time in the airport, waiting for food at a restaurant, chilling after dinner, etc), always worth a few laughs. It makes you think and tests your creativity. 

Highly recommend this to anyone, seasoned gamers and new gamers alike. Great family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I typically dislike party games, I don't like word games, this game has both and it is fun.  Vlaada Chavatil is a genius.  You try to give a single word clue and number of cards that matches words on a 5x5 grid of cards assigned to you as the clue giver but unknown to your team member.  Your team then tries to guess without picking the assassin card, neutral card or another team's card.  

It is nicely balanced with good components for a party game.  Now, it is not the greatest game ever.  The clue giver may take a lot of time to develop a clue.  It is light but this is a great gateway party game for both gamers and non gamers

RATING: 10

This has pretty much replaced all other party games for me.  At least for the moment.
Especially with the prospect of mixing in Dixit cards...

Update:  Picture cards are ok, but not as good as words.  I'll stick with the original for the most part.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great party game.  I'd suggest at least 6 players and people who've got a little bit of patience and enjoy analyzing clues.  As the clue giver it can take some time to figure out relevant, helpful clues that maximize the amount of cards it can apply to, so there can be down time, a lot of down time depending on the players and the cards.

The game is pretty quick for even non-gamers to pick up, but you might have to explain some concepts in the game a couple of times for it to "click" with new players.  Usually the best way teach this game is a quick run down of game and then an example round.  I also advise that the first two clue givers be experienced players when playing with new players.

Only cons are that there can be a lot of down time for clue givers, I recommend using a time, hourglass or digital to keep the pace of the game moving a decent speed.  Also the randomness of the cards drawn and the layout of the clues each team is to give, can sometimes lead to some really difficult clues to give for clue givers.

I've found that it's a very approachable, enjoyable game for all ages and levels of gaming experience.  Highly recommended for you party game collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Project this game on multiple monitors: 

primary monitor:
  *  key map generator;
  *  documents(rules_EN & rules_RO & rules_EN Pictures version);
  *  demo (video EN & video RO & video EN Picture version);
  *  add custom word lists (by category);
  * ~ 200 images, Pictures version;

on second monitor:
  * words table;

RATING: 7
Another chance to play this great game. Everyone must know it by now, and if they don't, they will do later this year when Codenames: Pictures hits the stores.

This was a chance to play the game with adults, which was a new experience and it did enhance my enjoyment of the game as you can think outside the box a little bit more when giving clues as the spymaster. 

I am though increasingly finding myself absolutely useless at it. These plays further compounded this opinion. I guess like everyone else I find myself giving clues that seem obvious or at least slightly clear but then once the one word clue leaves my mouth it becomes all to obvious from the looks on the faces of my eager spies that the word I was looking for to describe the clarity of my clue was opaque. For example, one game I was giving a clue that linked Tokyo and Calf and they thought I was hinting at a famous basketball player! With hindsight I can completely see their thought process and it was, I guess the obvious thing to think of, it just never entered my thought pattern

RATING: 8.5
[b]Great game for people who love guessing words. A lot thinkier and quieter than other party games because as the spymaster, you can only give a single word and number as the clue, and you have to be very careful about it so your team doesn't accidentally guess the assassin. It's exciting and nerve-wrecking to watch your team mates discuss your clue. And very interesting to see how different the connections are that other people's minds make from your own.[/b]

RATING: 7
This wasn't quite the hit with my family that I was expecting. In the end, we'd rather play Taboo or Password.

What made this fall flat, I think, was that there was a lack of tension. As long as you were ahead of the other team at all, you could give single-word clues and win. You didn't have to take risks to give multi-word clues.

For whatever reason, it also seemed to lack the "fun factor" that's essential for group games. Everyone was participating, but there wasn't any laughter or "wow" moments.

RATING: 5

However, I feel the game has been overplayed to death at this point.  I've seen many players, especially new ones, give simple clues to list only one card because sometimes the cards are just not in your favor.

To me, I prefer something a little bit more meatier.  If people want to play it, I'm happy to play it, but owning it?  I prefer to play other games in my collection.

RATING: 8
Definitely a different sort of word/puzzle game. I like it!

2v2: Being the spymaster was surprisingly stressful. I fucked up a lot in the first game, but improved a lot in my second. There are meta-layers of information that build up during play, and familiarity between teammates develops as well, which makes for an interesting dynamic. Being the guesser was fun, but on balance I think I enjoyed spymastering more -- although I was better at guessing.

It's a game that looks simple on the surface, and has simple rules, but which has layers and depth and elements that don't show themselves immediately. I love that. I also suspect it has more to reveal with other groups, play counts, etc.

RATING: 8.5
Codenames offers a solid fun experience. Initially my biggest doubt was how well the game works with non-native English speakers but the rules are flexible enough as long as all the players focus on the fun part of the game instead of nitpicking. Actually using foreign words brings a lot of new connections between words.
The game really deserves its #1 party game rank. Fast, simple and fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating based on many counts of players.

Simple and clever game. I brought this to a video game convention, and it was beloved by all.  It's one of those games where there's lots of potential to discuss and agonize over every decision, and it's good for friends AND for getting to know people. 

The possible issues that might arise is if the spymaster plays too conservatively and keeps doing _____ 1 hints (which can get a little boring) or if they're a  little AP-prone, but since the SM changes each round and there's a timer included those problems are minimal (we never used the timer ourselves).

---------------------------------
Over time this game has lost some of its lustre for me, as being the spymaster is by far the most interesting part of the game for me, and I don't like being part of a big team while guessing. I still like the game, but I like it 2v2 the most... but how often do you play it 2v2? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Almost always prefers to play codenames picture. (CN:pictures works much better in multilingual environments.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An amazing party game. One that I will almost always consider bringing or pulling out if I'm with a group of people who seem like they might even be slightly interested in playing a boardgame.

It just does everything right:
* It can be taught in less than 5 minutes.
* You instantly start feeling the tension of the game.
* It satisfies the cravings for people who love over-thinking things.
* It creates memorable moments in every game.
* And it has the boardgame-y rules that clearly define the bounds of the game (a problem with a lot of party games: "do whatever you want!").

A classic party game from the start. And it's easily expand-able, so it will have a lot of staying power. The only reason I have a couple of points knocked off it's rating (8/10) is because there's ultimately not much here. It's an amazing concept, but in terms of awe-inspiring game mechanism, there's not much beyond just the concept. But it's still great, and exactly what it needs to be IMO. Definitely recommended for anyone who might ever be in a group of people who would be interested in playing a light party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game for even non gamers. Really the only draw back is you need at least 4 pretty intelligent people to play.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy the word/gameplay, and the risk of sudden death greatly adds to the tension. Plus the meta-analysis of "How do they think I think?". I've found this game works well for a wide range of players in terms of age, game experience, etc but avoid people who are non-cooperative (stick to competitive games for them).

So very solid game, but fyi two minor weaknesses:
1) the downtime can kind of kill the pace, and
2) sometimes the word distribution heavily favors one team (but this occurs infrequently).

The first can be reduced by having both team leaders thinking, regardless of whose turn it is (can help save a lot of time that way, except for very first turn). And by using the hourglass (despite the rules' suggestion to use it rarely) when people's interest starts waning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Really simple idea, quick game and fun, but somehow I don't see anything really special about it, maybe that's because I didn't played with 7 other people yet.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great party game.  Quick, intellectual and fun.

I wish it were a little easier to explain (maybe I haven't done it enough).  The vagueness of the rules (specifically what you can and can't do) is a double edged sword.  I like the flexibility, but it makes it annoying to explain.  I wish it came with a cheat sheet of the rules too.

Another thing that makes the game difficult is that new folks don't full accept the Spy theme.  The theme is important because real spies don't give away answers with their body language or prefacing their clues with "this might be a stretch" or laughing at their teammates as they work out the answers.

RATING: 9.5
[b]2015-09-10 9.5[/b] After 9 Plays:
I'm obsessed with this game. Been playing it remotely in a 2p co-operative game but it doesn't feel dull at all. Surprisingly thinky for a filler game. RATING: 3
I loved the game the first time I played it and absolutely hated it the next time. I've played it several times always hopping to be able to enjoy it again and I just can't get past how random and unbalanced it is! 90% of the games I've played have been total blowouts because one side just got better sets of words to work with... The game is just too long to have no real balance.

I like the core concept and might play the game again if they ever release designed cards with nice themed and pre balanced sets of words (and no random grid) to guarantee a close match. Random words with a random grid is far too random for a competitive game that takes this lomg.

RATING: 8

The included timer is also a great way to prevent players from slow-rolling the game without being too oppressive or another aspect of the game to worry about.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really fun team game about picking the right clue to group as many of words as possible without risking your group picking either the opponent team's words (giving them an advantage) or the hidden spy-word that automatically loses you the game.

For people playing whose first language isn't English (as is the case in my group) it's worth noting that you should have an idea of your group's English skills before suggesting this game, as I was surprised to learn that several of my fellow players were less competent in the language than I had assumed. However, it was fun despite some confusion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Very accessible, good for a wide range of groups.  Quick to play and easy to teach.  Encourages creativity and deduction.  Creates memorable moments, win or lose.  Some rounds are duds due to random card setup.  Teammate's skill level and enthusiasm can make or break the experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Got this game to play with non-gamer family. First play through was successful. Agree with others that it is better if you have 2-3 people guessing. After 2 plays with just teams of 2, it felt lacking. Once more people were added it got better.

Update: I have played this with probably 20 different people over the course of owning it.

When it shines: If your code masters are able to connect brain waves with their people. If you can get 3+ in a turn it is amazing.

When it needs help: If the code master is struggling, it can be a terrible experience. They take forever to find more than one card and just give up and only flip one card a turn. Those rounds are embarrassing for everyone. Major analysis paralysis sometimes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Very good party game, while it demands more attention than others of the same kind.

PROS
- Unique mechanic, very interesting with the right group.
- A "metagame" can be developed through some consecutive games.
- Both fantastic and terrible clues are remembered for months.

CONS
- Requires a high amount of concentration to be a party game.
- Some players can be overwhelmed when being Leaders.

RATING: 10
Yet another excellent game by Vlaada. Super simple to explain, super practical to play (any amount of players of any age split in two teams), super flexible (we’ve had people jump in half-way seamlessly) and super fun. Word games are simple to design but very tricky to get right, and Codenames is a prime example of high value. Only caveat - everyone needs to speak the language well, I tried to play the English version with non-English speakers and it didn’t go too well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My friend Matt said it best. While I was putting Codenames away after playing it for several hours, he commented "I understand why we're going to play something else, but I would easily play that game for the rest of the day."

Codenames is a rare breed of game. I will introduce new players to the rules, and after their first turn, they immediately understand the entire game. Codenames is a straightforward game, though it is still tense and exciting, and each game only lasts about 15 minutes. (It doesn't overstay its welcome.)

Codenames is the sort of game that sticks with you. I still remember games when my team picked the assassin on our first guess (which made our team immediately lose). I also remember games when my team came back from a staggering 4 cards behind to win the game. Though the game itself is short, Codenames is the sort of game that stays with you.

Highly, highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Definitely a solid party game, with some nice opportunities for "gamer" tactics, the stuff you find in other party games that are popular here (Dixit, Wits & Wagers, etc.). In this case, you want to very carefully select your clues such they point out only your own words and not your opponents'--and definitely not the assassin's. This can actually lead to a little "brainburn," which I hold against other games of this type, but somehow don't find offensive here.

RATING: 9
And man... what can I say? Vlaada is a Genius and as done it again!!!

He managed to put a game in a Party Game... it's easy to play, to explain, anyone can play it, you can play it with 4 players or with 40!

It's FUN, but it also has skill in it, it's not just a random funny game where you just do stuff!

In this one the toughest role is being the Spymaster... trying to link the words you want your team to guess without getting the oter teams words or even worse the assassin can be very challenging!

But the role of the other players isn't easy either, they have to get inside the mind of the spymaster and decipher properly the clue he gives.

I usually don't like word games, don't like party games but this one, despite being both things is just AWESOME!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Two thoughts come to mind when I think of Codenames:
"What an amazing party game"
and
"This is the most stressful game I have every played"

It seems like it would be so easy to come up with one-word clues that cover multiple words in a way your partner will understand. This is not true.

Codenames is surprisingly psychological, as you must try to imagine how your partner, completely in the dark, will interpret your word as it connects to 25 other words on the table. The feeling of pulling off a clever clue to get 3 or more words is one of triumph.

Vlaada Chvátil manages to do the impossible here: design an AP-prone party game. The game is very short, but some turns can feel like an eternity as nothing seems to fit and you either go for a clue which is a long shot or just go for a 1-word clue.

Definitely worth picking up, as it provides very interesting situations and can be played pretty much anywhere and anytime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
highly recommended party game. Fun for the whole family!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Need to have the right group but it can be alot of fun. Several friends own this
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I hate party games, and I'm not a big fan of word games either. But I have a great fondness for Codenames. 

For me, it stands out from most party games in that it doesn't simply present me with a blank canvas and put me on the spot to come up with something creative or funny. I'm much too slow and plodding of a thinker to do well in those kinds of situations, and I end up having a miserable time at games that require that sort of spontaneity.

It also stands out from most word games in that it's not quite so dry and lacking in context. Games like Scrabble or Boggle ask you to come up with words that fit, but any word will do, so long as it obeys the rules. The meanings of the words never make an appearance. In Codenames, the meanings of the words *are* the game.

It's tremendously fun to try to stretch your brain to connect seemingly unconnected words, and fun to guess at what connection the spymaster had in mind. There's also plenty of room for some clever analysis as you try to figure out why the spymaster chose one clue instead of another.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So simple, it's hard to believe it just came out. But it's a lot of fun. And it plays so fast, you're bound to play it again immediately.

RATING: 7.9
The spymaster role in this game is extremely important & demanding:  if the spymaster cannot think of multiple word clues and only gives a clue for "one" word at a time: the game kind of falls apart because it is stupidly easy.  So the game requires smart, creative spymasters.  When there are good spymasters the game is addictive & fun: it is the kind of game that you can't play just once! When the spymaster is slow, or limited to single-word clues, there's really no game at all. 

(With Pictures, it's easier to find matches.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
+1 Creates fun, laughter and banter. 
+2 Very flexible player numbers - tolerates adding/removing spies mid game, people not paying attention, going for a drink etc. 
+1 reasonable degree of skill for the 'spy masters' 
+1 very light game can teach in 20 seconds if you're a spy. 

-2 can be a LOT of downtime for everyone else if one of the spymasters can't think of a clue (or, the flipside, every clue is a 1 and the game becomes very easy on both sides). Which, for a party game, is huge.   
-.5 game tends to irk rules lawyers - people giving 'hints' or bending rules etc.
-.5 Plays less 'laughs and banter' with less than 5/6 players. Lots of silent thinking doesn't suit a party game. 


Fantastic as an overflow table for meetups. provided there's a spymaster who knows how to play, we can add/remove players almost at will, and it still runs fine. encourages banter/chats between folks, people can wander, not pay attention, get drinks etc. Codenames tolerates it all and still works fine.

RATING: 10
A perfect party game if people can focus and pay attention the game, at least (I don't think it's a great party game when drinking necessarily).

The design is good, and it's even more fun with larger teams, like 6 or 8 people, when each team can discuss with each other how to reason.

Considering its rank and rating, it's really hard to beat when the price is as low as it is. It's a bargain and you should pick it up, unless you really don't like this kind of game (like word games) or rarely play together with more people (4+).

I will give it a slight minus to the fact that the box really could have benefited from an inlay of any kind.

RATING: 9
I picked up a copy of this a Gen Con.  I played it with two players and it was fun but it was extremely easy.  I don't recommend it with 2 or even 3.  I was able to play it later with 8 players and it worked so extremely well.  We had spymasters squirming and general hilarity.  When my husband gave the clue "wood 2" as our first clue and we looked at the cards and saw; deck, chest, bark, nut, maple and palm the entire table exploded in shouting, recriminations and laughter.  We picked deck first and it was completely wrong.  It will be a long time before he lives that clue down.  We are still all laughing about it days later.  Great game for bigger groups.  I would play it any day with 4 or more.  I won't play it again with 2 or 3.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bei Codenames stehen sich zwei Teams von Agenten gegenüber. Jedes Team hat einen Gruppenleiter, der dafür sorgen muss, dass sein Team die Agenten der eigenen (Team-)Farbe findet. Dafür liegen in der Mitte Karten mit Begriffen aus. Die beiden Gruppenchefs sehen ganz genau, wo sich welcher Agent befindet. Und nun gilt es, dass die Hinweise geben, hinter welchem Wort sich ein eigener Agent befindet. Zum Beispiel kann er sagen "Säugetier - 2". Daraus schließt das eigene Team, dass sich hinter zwei "Säugetier"-Begriffen eigene Agenten befinden. Wenn sich jetzt nur ein Elefant und ein Schwein auf den Karten befindet, war der Tipp super. Was aber wenn es auch noch einen Wal und eine Antilope gibt? Das Spielprinzip ist schnell erklärt und anschließend Jedem klar. Die Gruppenchefs haben hier die schwerste Aufgabe, nämlich Verbindungen zwischen den Begriffen verbinden. "Um die Ecke" denken ist angesagt. Super tolles und witziges Spielprinzip! Aber man sollte es früh auf einer Party auspacken. Ist zuviel Alkohol geflossen wird das nix mehr :-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great party game. Love playing it with both family and friends.

RATING: 8
Simply social-teamwork deduction gaming executed perfectly to be a fun and interesting time for non-gamers and gamers alike. 

A pair of team leaders must offer a single word clue to try and direct their team towards picking various words in a grid (thematically they are agents) and the first team to get their words first wins. 

The fun of course is in creating creative clues and then seeing your team screw them up completely.

A game that should be in every collection and could easily be a household name if marketed right over the next 20 years. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is probably the best party game that I own. Unsurprising, considering it's ranked number 1 on BGG for party games!

To play this, you need two "spymasters", and each spymaster should be assisted by a team of at least two players. The exact player count is not important, but I do think that it needs at least 6 players to be enjoyable. This game highly rewards skilled play. It is a word-guessing game, but it also has a high amount of strategy, which makes it the perfect choice for any kind of group; both gamers and casual fans can have fun together. If you have enough players, you can't go wrong with this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It sounds so simple on paper. The ONLY reason this game works so well is the Codenames themselves; whilst they feel quite arbitrary, they have been painstakingly chosen by the game's creators to just share enough through-lines to make it work. Really easy to learn, Codenames is a very simple game of word association which requires teams to really tap in to each other's mind-sets to succeed. Playing with close friends and playing with acquaintances becomes a very different beast.  I'd wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.91
The game just works - at any player count, odd, even, few, plenty. One of the most versatile games in my collection, and with the abundance of words, the game has so much replay value. There is a reason it is so highly talked about.

Easy to make yourself too, but I bought simply because it can be excellent to give out the best clue ever - only to have them second guess it because they didn't think you meant that.

Can be prone to people that have a better vocabulary winning but it's not a problem anyway because the people that guess the clues have to be equally as understanding, and that can lead to some interesting developments.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a nice compact design by Vlaada Chvatil. There are two teams. For each team, there is a spymaster, a person who gives clues for the other person to guess. Clues are in the form of a word follwed by a number e.g. animal 2, which means the spymaster wants their team to look for 2 words related to animals. The words are laid out in a 5 X 5 grid, and each time you identify a word correctly, it is marked with your team's colour. But if you guess wrong, you could uncover the opponent's words, or neutral words, or worse, the assasin which results in an instant loss for your team. 

The game can be played as a party game, as a filler or a serious game where you want to give the best clues. It's fun and educational at the same time. For instance, one word I had to give a clue to was a platypus, but someone told me afterwards it was the only mammal that lays eggs. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Works beautifully whether at my weekly game group or at a family get-together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Got a chance to play this and even though I don't think I'll need it for my collection since there will be other games I'd rather play more for this particular mood such as Mafia De Cuba, Spyfall etc. I think the fact is this is a wonderful party game that I would rather play instead of monikers or Cranium if I'm going to compare it to other team based party games that many people can play. Excellent game. Vlaada hits it out of the park again. A down side is that the tension can almost be "too high" for how light it is. It's hard to explain but weirdly, it's a game that is easy for people to take too seriously too easily.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It’s often a little too easy to bend and stretch the rules of Codenames in a way that undermines its integrity as a team-based competition, so it’s perhaps better evaluated on its merits as a low-investment party game. That said, the consistently tenuous connections generated by clue masters provokes both elaborate mental gymnastics and raucaus laughter, making for a very satisfying passtime. 

Approved.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b] This game is incredibly easy to teach, and quick enough that people won't dislike it based on length and complexity. 

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b] The inclusion of the assassin was essential. It adds intensity to the game beyond worrying about choosing the other teams agents. Because of the way the game is set up, and the way the spymasters cards are plentiful and can be rotated in any way, and also that customizing this game is incredibly easy,  the replayability of this game is infinite.

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b] This game is incredibly easy to find for a good price. Short of an apocalyptic event, this game will remain in print for a long, long time.

[b][COLOR=#66CC33]Pro:[/COLOR][/b] This game can often times be funny. You can give the perfect clue, and your group of friends will twist that clue into something that you did not intend at all if they don't know where you were going. I've also had times where absolutely no clue I've givens should've pointed to the assassin, but if anything could find a way to bastardize your intentions, it's a group of your friends.

[b][COLOR=#FF0033]Con:[/COLOR][/b] If I were to nitpick, sometimes the cards one team has are easier to link than cards another team has. But, considering how quickly a round (or even the entire game) ends makes this "flaw" very insignificant.



[i][COLOR=#33CCFF]Final thoughts:[/COLOR]  Because of the extreme accessibility of this game, plus the nearly infinite amount of replay ability value, plus the additional expansions like code names pictures that could be mixed into the base game with no major issue... It's just fantastic. It's enjoyable for people of all ages, and I feel like any type of gamer could enjoy it. Even when your friends connect completely different words than you expect, it can still be fun to see them work out what clues they think you're giving.                [/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
The quality of the components is average. The sand timer was broken and the cardstock is not great. It should not be a problem because the cards will not sustain heavy use.

Codenames is a word association game not related in any way to spies. The rules are very, very simple, and the setup is fast. You will be playing 5 minutes after opening the box. And you will have fun. Because it plays out better than expected when you read the rules.

There's a couple of issues with Codenames:
[b]AP[/b]: There's a risk of serious AP here. Obviously, the more time you think, the more likely you are to come up with better word associations. The sand timer will be a must with certain players.
[b]Catch-up[/b]: If one team fails and chooses a spot belonging to their rivals, it will be almost impossible for them to come back from that. It's not a big issue, because rounds are short.
[b]Clues[/b]: There can be some dissensions about what might constitute a legal clue, and what not. The rulebook already advances some of them.
[b]Rule of silence[/b]: There are many comments or reactions from the clue-givers that can be interpreted as a [n illegal] clue (rightly so). 

None of these issues spoils the fun as long as you don't play in an hyper-competitive way. I personally prefer not enforcing the "rule of silence"; I enjoy more when people laughs and comments on what happens in the game.

It has an unlimited replayability and I think 6 players is the sweet spot. But it works well with 8 too, and although it's not ideal, an uneven number of players (5-7) will work too. I have not tried it,but it might be fine with more or less players too.

Overall, it's a great party game based on a very simple idea. Another masterwork of Vlaada in a new genre for him.

First impression [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/202797/item/4366822#item4366822]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Codenames[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (6):[/COLOR]

[i]Somehow I haven't played this again even though it seems to be everywhere. I'm not sure if it is the game itself or my general feelings towards party games. I'd much rather play a filler than party game so I've yet to play Codenames again. I wouldn't refuse to play, but I'm not seeking it out either. That said I did enjoy my one session playing and wouldn't mind trying it again. I'm just doubtful it would ever beat out Diamant, Cockroach Poker or Camel Up when we game with our extended family.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]Both of my plays were with 2 and I had a blast. I definitely think 4 or 6 would be the sweet spot for me. It can definitely induce some AP, especially when the board is fresh and you have to look at everything to make sure your clues aren't too broad. I could see busting this out with our extended family, but since those opportunities are infrequent I still would rather play games like Camel Up, Cash n' Guns, Diamant or Cockroach Poker. I also think this would be a tough game for kids, especially if they were giving the clues (who knows though maybe I'm completely wrong about that).

As of now definitely a game I'd enjoy playing again, but probably not one I'll add to my collection anytime soon (although I am curious what my wife would think of it as a 2p game).[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
規則:
*分紅藍兩隊，兩隊各一個隊長，中間牌5*5的題目，隊長看題解卡
*題解卡周遭顏色代表起始隊伍顏色，目標會多一
*紅色藍色分別是兩隊要猜的，白色沒差，黑色的猜到就輸了
*輪流由隊長說出一個單字跟一個數字，數字代表與此單字相關的字卡數量，可討論，隊友想辦法猜出對應的字卡，猜中可繼續猜到比數字多一次
*猜到自己以外的都停住，並放對應圖板，猜到刺客就輸了
*兩隊輪流到先猜完全部的獲勝
*隊長給無效線索時，另一對可以擺一個特務到場上
*數字可以給0，此時猜測次數沒有上限
***兩人遊戲***
*你們一定是首家，輪到對手時幫他選擇一個答案放上去
**三人***
*猜測玩家同時幫兩個隊長工作
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
best game for party games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Engaging enough to get lots of replay, but lots of downtime if you want it played well. Trying to find a clue that that your team will associate with as many of your cards as possible, but none of the opponents, and certainly not the insta-death card, is pure downtime for everyone else, so hope that they and the other team are friends and can chat among themselves while it gets worked out. But that is also the source of enjoyment and satisfaction that the game offers, when your teammates correctly associate a given clue with more than just a word or two. It's more of a thinker filler than a fun filler, but it has its place and it's generated itself a ton of replay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A perfect game. Excellent design. Simple to teach. Accessible.

RATING: 7
