=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"Party game, sort of. It's like a party game for nerdy people who find brainburners to be fun."

What I like:
- The game design is incredibly clever
- Everyone else seems to love it
- It plays reasonably quickly, and makes you think
- The co-op mode is a nice touch

What I don't like:
- I would rather play a non-party game
- Co-op mode is OK but not great
- A lot of the rules are fuzzy, left up to the group
- Clue-givers have to be completely flat, which reduces the fun factor

At 2-5p, I would rather play it as a co-op; at 6 or more, I prefer it with teams. It's best with 3-4 or 6+. It's a title I have to own because it serves a purpose, but I will never suggest it. 

I'm not a Vlaada fan, but this is definitely one of his best games.

RATING: 10
This is an absolutely fantastic party game, with near-infinite replayability!  As spymaster, trying to come up with the perfect clue that will not connect to anything the opposing team has (or, worse yet, the assassin) is quite a difficult puzzle, which gets slightly easier as the game goes on.  As a generic team member, trying to figure out what your spymaster had in mind for a clue in particular was also a delicious puzzle in many cases.  This is as perfect a party game as you'll ever find.

RATING: 9
Another quick party game and there are a few good ones but many of these I can't stand. Codenames on the other hand is a blast to play. A simple mechanic where one code master gives a hint and number to indicate how many cards match that hint, then the players must try to determine which of the face up cards the code master is trying to get you to pick out as there is a set of words that need to be selected to win. The table talk is great as people get on strange tangents to get the hint to match the clues. The game is quick to learn and really interactive and just a blast to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Codenames is a pretty clever word association-style party game. Players are separated into teams consisting of one clue-giver and a number of guessers. The clue-giver comes up with a word that will allow his team to guess as many of their team's words on the board as possible without hitting an opponent's word. My main complaint with the game is that it seems way more fun to be a clue-giver than a guesser. Despite this, it's an interesting take on the party game genre that we haven't really seen before. 

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I'm utterly baffled as to how this game has been rated so highly. It's relentlessly boring. Long do-nothing waits while the clue-givers decide on a word, long do-nothing waits while the other team chooses their word. A canonical example of a game that's playtime is characterized more by non-play than play.

RATING: N/A
CC-COA
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a game I went into expecting to just kind of like it, I loved it. The rules, while not hard, are difficult to explain without playing a game of it first. You have one person per side trying to give clues to the other players on their side. They want to get all their words chosen before the other team. The trick is, you can only use 1 word and you have to avoid the assassin word which will instantly lose you the game.

If I owned this, Wits and Wagers and Telestrations, I doubt I'd ever have to buy another party game again. Doesn't replace a gamer party game, but man is this game good with everyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Deduction party game that can be a real brain burner and have some actual game play rather than just be a group activity.  It's a workout for your brain to play this.

We have really enjoyed this and has been a surprise hit.

Edit: Played this some more and have come to realize that you need to play this with the right group of people. We have had this game completely fall flat for some. It was just too boring and slow for some even with the egg timer in play for both spymasters and guessers.

These experiences have hurt the game a bit for us and have caused me to lower the score a point. It's a cerebral game that takes some patience. Not a good game to play when tired from the day. People probably need to be into word games and abstraction.

That said it is still one of the better party games available but, some people are going to prefer werewolf over this (which in turn I personally hate). Understand your audience before introducing this game. 

This game is hard enough for adults. I really doubt those under 14 can be good at this game. Also found that people who have a hard time with abstract concepts and symbolic connections really struggle with this game as clues often require some less than literal thinking. In order to really succeed at the game you need to get 2 guesses per turn on average correct and that requires some outside the box thinking. Not everyone is cut out for that.

This game has taught me that some people are really literal thinkers that have a hard time making conceptual abstract connections. It may seem obvious to some but it really isn't to others. Part of the game is understanding how people think and adapting to it.

Always use the timer. Otherwise people will take ages to come up with clues or make guesses.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Finally cracked this open, as it's been sitting on my shelves in shrink since we bought it waiting for a family game night to take it for a spin.  My wife and I wanted to try it out, so we played a couple of two player games, each taking a turn at being the spymaster.  It was more fun than I thought.  A decent word game.  It is not as easy as it can look, trying to come up with a word that works as a clue for as many words as you can, especially in the two player variant (I know it is not the ideal way to play but we went with what we had) where you are trying to clear your words with as many enemies as possible still on the board.  I can see where this will be a lot of fun in its intended setting:  a large group, or when we take it to family game night and the whole family is playing.

As I expected, it went over like gangbusters with my family, so much that I think I may give this copy to my sister as a little gift.  She loves it and while I think it is a decent game, I really do not understand the hype behind it and would not miss it.

**EDIT:   Traded away in my very first Math Trade.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The rules are simple but the game has enough variation to keep me playing again and again. As one of the clue-givers, you get a bit of a mental workout - which I like, as you try to link as many of your team's words as you can in an attempt to get them to guess them all before your opposite number does that for his or her team. I personally prefer to play without the timer, although sometimes it is a good idea (and more tense if you do) if you're playing against a clue-giver who you may feel is taking too much time on their turn. As I said above, there is so much variation. This is because there are so many different card combinations available. This is just a really great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
One of the hit games of 2015. This is now my first-choice gateway game for introducing to non-gamers. I have now played it as a gateway game with dozens of non-gamers and almost all are hooked and tell me they are going to buy a copy to play with their friends and family. Several find it such a revelation that I get begged to recommend other games they should try. Unlike most 'word' games (eg: Scrabble), it requires some actual understanding of the words. It is quick to teach and learn. Main problem is that the 25-word starting grid makes for an often painfully slow start, with the Spymasters having initially to take a lot in. The game has endless possibilities for development: it is easy to add your own words, and it can be used as an educational tool for language learners by slipping in foreign vocabulary. I have also been experimenting with variants to appeal to wider audiences; for example, you can play with movie buffs by demanding that all clues must be movie titles.

Among 'expansions' for this game, I have a Bonus Pack of cards (EN01) that was a promo in Spielbox 01/17. The Bonus Pack is subtitled 'Board Gaming' but it is playable because the words aren't titles and authors of board games (as in an earlier largely useless expansion) but words with a gaming association (like Euro and Family).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played this with a random group of strangers and it was OK.  If I played this with friends it would probably shoot up to a 9

So I finally got the opportunity to play this game with friends, and it was amazing!  Pulled this out during Friendsgiving and by the end of the night everyone was playing it.  I was really surprised because Beer Pong usually is the game that dominates when we have people over, but due to the lack of an available table (from all of the food) we tried this out instead and it wouldn't shock me if some of my friends would prefer to play this over Beer Pong.  Which is saying alot because these are ex-college people in there mid-20's feeling this way.

Played this again during New Years and there was an available Pong table so this game had direct competition.  This still had more players throughout the night than the Pong table and this is in the same setting as the Friendsgiving party (very competitive Pong players).  Best party game by a long shot.

RATING: 3
This will fizzle out: I was really surprised at how disappointed I was after I played it. 

If I hadn't know it was by a reputable designer like Vlaada beforehand, that would have been a jaw-dropping revelation afterwards. I mean, I wouldn't have been surprised if this had been just another nameless Hasbro-style party game. 

The game can grind to a halt if a spymaster isn't well suited to clue engineering. And unbalanced teams in terms of innate abilities gives that team a significant advantage. Both of these can be avoided if players are divided into teams in the right way, and certain players are not made to be the spymaster. And because it's a short game, these aren't super-problems. But even with really smart/clever spymasters, getting clues that could point to 3 or more words proved really difficult, which also makes the game quite slow (for what it is). 

Party games are different than other kinds of games for sure. But there are a lot of fun ones out there already, and this one only stands out because it's new. I don't mean to be harsh, but this will fade. Some groups of people will love it -- which is great! -- but there certainly isn't anything special or amazing about it. In a word: forgettable.

RATING: 8
14+(10+); 2-8(6-8); 15mins

In playing Codenames, at the back of my mind, I'm thinking BGG needs to broaden their categories to move this '#1 Party Game' to '#1 Word Game' as the game is AP inducing and I have to remind myself that I too should use the sand timer otherwise it just isn't that FUN. 
In fact using the sand timer and putting pressure has more chance of evoking head slapping moments, which should be hilarious so long as competition isn't fierce and it isn't team mates that are doing the head slapping or finger pointing. 

Otherwise this is a very good, tense, engaging word game, with some theme at least but really good in that it is challenging to 'network' popular perceived meanings associated with the words on display, and it doesn't suffer the mastery effect like in Taboo whereby getting good at avoiding taboo words takes away the fun, because there is little promise in Codenames of GIGGLES or BELLY LAUGHS which I think is the defining factors to get the label 'party game'.

RATING: 9
This is a brilliant little game. It looks so simple and is easy to explain, but becomes tough when you find out just how differently your brain works to your friends'. So many times I've given a seemingly watertight clue, only to have my team go for something completely random! Highly recommended and very replayable. 

The only disadvantage is that there can be a bit of a wait if someone's struggling to think of a clue, but the game comes with an optional hourglass for that very reason...
 
Someone suggested replacing the word cards with Dixit or Once Upon A Time for an extra challenge: will have to try that out soon.

RATING: 8
A fun word/party game that is easy to teach. The two different roles (spymaster and spy) feel very different, and both feel like you're really stretching your understanding of the words and your teammates the whole time. It can be very satisfying to successfully get a big clue, and it can be funny for both teams when someone fails. Because of the way the game works, you seldom have those annoying word-game situations where people are arguing over whether a word is valid or not. When the round ends, people always want to talk about the game, like "What were you thinking when you gave that clue?". That's the sign of a good game that is engaging the players.

RATING: N/A
This game contains three sizes of cards.

Large cards (agent, assassin, double agent, and innocent bystander cards): - The agent, assassin, and double agent 'cards' are actually tiles, and durable enough to not require sleeving. They're listed here for the sake of completeness anyway. There are 17 of them in total, so if you don't sleeve them, you'll need 7 sleeves.
Number of cards: 25

Mayday sleeve size: Sails of Glory - Orange/Yellow (MDG-7126, 100/pack) - (50 x 75mm)
Swan PanAsia sleeve size: 51x77 (SWN-012, 160/pack) - (51 x 77mm)
Thai Boardgame sleeve size: Wiz-War Classic 1st-6th edition (2"x3") for 50.5x76mm cards (120/pack)

Small cards (code name cards):
Number of cards: 200

Arcane Tinmen sleeve size: Small - Red (AT-10404, 100/pack) - (44 x 68mm)
Fantasy Flight sleeve size: Mini European - Red (FFS02, 50/pack) - (1-11/16” x 2-5/8" - 44 x 68mm)
Mage Company sleeve size: Mini European (MCG 024, 50/pack) - (47 x 71mm)
Mayday sleeve size: Mini Euro - Light Blue: Standard (MDG-7035, 100/pack) or Premium (MDG-7080, 50/pack) - (45 x 68mm)
MTL sleeve size: Soft MEU (MTL145, 100/pack) - (45 x 68mm)
Swan PanAsia sleeve size: Mini Euro: Standard (SWN-006, 160/pack) or Premium (SWN-502, 100/pack) - (45 x 70mm)
Thai Boardgame sleeve size: #5 for 44x68mm cards (120/pack)
Ultimate Guard sleeve size: Mini European: Premium (UGD010277, 50/pack) or Supreme (UGD010076, 50/pack) - (46 x 71mm)
Ultra-Pro sleeve size: Mini European - Purple (82661, 50/pack) - (44 x 68mm)

Number of cards: 40

Thai Boardgame sleeve size: #7 for 70x70mm cards (100/pack)
Ultimate Guard sleeve size: Board Game Square Size: Premium (UGD010283, 50/pack) or Supreme (UGD010113, 50/pack) - (73 x 73mm)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very light, fun party game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Codenames is a two-team game that features wordplay. A 5x5 tableau of cards is layed out, each card consisting of a word (except sometimes there are two words, like ice cream). One player for each team is the spymaster, and has access to a hidden tableau showing which words correspond to that team's agents. The spymasters take turns giving clues, consisting of a single word (which relates to some number of words on the table) and the number of words that correspond to that clue word. The other players on the team then have to choose (by physically touching the word card) which cards they think are their agents. If they're correct, the card is covered with an agent tile of the correct color, otherwise, their turn ends because they've found a non-agent, an agent of the other team, or the sole assassin which autowins the game for the other player. Players must choose at least one card each turn, but may choose a number of cards equal to the number the spymaster gave them plus one. This allows for them to use this extra pick to snatch up cards that they missed out on in earlier turns. First team to find all their agents wins.

So. This is a game where the spymasters have to come up with word association, and then hope that this word association conveys itself properly to the lesser members of their team. So in essence, this is a word game that could be softly compared to games like Taboo, Train of Thought, and even Dixit in some ways, as the subtext of the word association can often be as helpful or hindering as the obvious associations.

But all I can think about is how this games design, mechanically, at its core... feels... obvious.

Saying that a game feels obvious makes ME feel like I'm that one obnoxiously pretentious panelist on a celebrity reality cooking show. I know. I'm so sorry. 

But if you recall, I compared this game to games like Taboo, or Train of Thought, or other types of word puzzle games. Because that's what this game is. The physical game is just a big random word generator, and random tableaus. The actual game emerges when you tell us to do word association. Dixit in many ways does a similar thing but with the tableau of words being a tableau of avant-garde pictures (I don't actually know what avant-garde means, so sorry for that oblique description), and with that game I love the art more than I love the game (which goes to say something considering my usually low opinion of art; in truth I just like pictures of things that are pleasant, which is why I'm so disappointed the ants battling on a pile of coins is not a picture ants battling on a pile of flapjacks). I don't think this is a bad game. I don't think it's a lazy game. But I think it is an obvious game. It's a game of word association. It's put together neatly, and does what it does well, but what it does is word association.

Codenames is a word game. There are lots of well known, and well ranked word games out there. But think about the places where you play word games, and think about the places you play other types of hobby games. There is certainly overlap, but they are not the same.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simply fantastic.

RATING: 6.5
Another one of those quick games that just get replayed a lot. This is going to be a classic and as such I just can't take much away from it. It's not my favorite game to play, but I do have to rate it highly.

UPDATE 10/12/17: Okay I lowered the rating from an 8 to 6.5 I know it's a big drop. I think BGG ratings are supposed to be more personal I generally try to go by the actual criteria listed for BGG ratings. Generally I like to play any strategy game over Codenames. I even like games like Sushi Go! over Codenames because Sushi Go is a game about decision making rather than about word knowledge and connections between people. It's not that I don't like Codenames, its just that personally I have a much bigger itch for strategy games. If I have an opportunity to play a game, I'd much rather it be a strategy game because I just don't get the opportunity to play strategy games that often. If I were to try to rate Codenames objectively, I'd rate it a 9 or 10 game. I think it's a classic and a great game objectively. Subjectively every time our group chooses to play this game I am really disappointed. 

Also I think Codenames Pictures is the better game. Its more lighthearted fun and people don't take it as seriously. Which is better because honestly Codenames is not supposed to be a serious game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros:
* Inexpensive
* Plays very well as a 2-player co-op.
* Quick setup
* The components aren't handled so it's a fine game to play with food/drinks.
* Tense and fun

Neutral:
* The cards aren't handled and they don't need to be shuffled so I haven't felt compelled to sleeve the game (which is good because there were 200 cards!)
* Seems ripe for a digital implementation.
* I suppose there could be some boring downtime if you're sitting around waiting for the spymaster to come up with a clue. For our 2p plays, we like to give the spymaster unlimited time and the operative just wanders off for a bit. This is a very unusual game in that this sort of "go find something to do while I take my turn" would normally be a "con" but we put it in the "pro" column because it gives us a game we can play while we're making dinner or cleaning the house.


= 2016-01-02 - R:8 (co-op), R:? (multi-player)

Really liking this one as a 2-player co-op. We like to play while we're doing other projects. The spymaster makes up a clue and then goes back to preparing the soup. The operative guesses and then goes back to doing dishes. No "downtime" :)

 Sometimes the words come up in such a way that we can't figure out clever/interesting connections between them and the game gets kind of dull, but then you just try something crazy, win or lose and try again.

I rarely feel this way, but I think I'd rather play this on a tablet/phone if given the choice.

As of two days ago, we've played this 12 times. Starting out at 8 for the co-op game. I suspect this rating will go up once we've tried it multi-player.

RATING: 3
Not sure why this game is so popular.  Simple to play; no challenge.  Whoever gets to go first usually wins
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
June 2017: Introduced this to a group of non-gamers and they all LOVED it. We improvised the game by drawing a 5x5 grid and filling them with words of our choice (which enabled us to use words you'd never, ever find in the published game) and the Codewords Gadget app. The clue-givers also wrote out their words on a separate sheet of paper (which was shared between them).

This, to me, is the equivalent of a Marvel movie. I could simply shut my brain off while playing and enjoy the ride.

As a party game, there are still two big issues for me:
1. The cross-referencing issue of finding your team's words on the grid -- but we solved this by letting the clue gives write their words in a list so that they don't ever need to look at the app again. Probably not in the spirit of the game, but they wouldn't have it any other way.
2. The downtime -- but my friends LOVE this as they tend to chat during the other team's turn.

March 2017: Really fiddly party game! As the clue giver, I wasn't willing to constantly cross-reference the private grid and the grid of words. So, I wrote down my words, the opposing team's words, and the "taboo" word. That made my turns incredibly fast as I can think of the next clue during the opposing team's turn.

But then, I'm hardly paying attention to the opposing team. So if I were playing according to the spirit of the game, there would be a lot of downtime!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pros:
1. Interesting. The clues that people come up with to connect words are amazing. There's always 1 clue where everyone is impressed. And there's always 1 clue where everyone is saying "Why the hell would you think that?". Either way, you end up with a great story.
2. Everyone Loves It. I have yet to play with people who did not like this game. Gamers love it. Family members love it. Non-gamers love it. It's just fun no matter what.
3. Replayability. There are a lot of word cards and each one is double sided. Not to mention the cards can be rearranged causing a whole new game with different clues. The base game can be played over and over, but you can easily add your own word cards if you wish.

Cons:
1. Silence. The clue giver can sometimes take a very long time trying to think up clues. They do provide you with a timer if this becomes an issue, but there are long bouts of silence if people are not good at thinking quickly on their feet.

Summary: This game is a must add to your collection. It is perfect for family holidays. I love using this game to wrap up or open up a gaming night. It plays fast, teaches easy and leads to lots of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I think this game is great and is probably best with larger player counts. We tend to only have 3 or 4 so it doesn't make it to the table as much as I'd like. I could see this game playing better with certain groups vs. others based on knowledge level and creativity. Certain clues are not going to be understood by certain age groups and players with a larger vocabulary will have an advantage when guessing but also possibly a disadvantage when giving clues. I'm still looking forward to trying this with Dixit cards instead of the words because we are big fans of Dixit.

RATING: 10
The best party game ever made. Period.

An instant hit in our group - everybody who tried it, loved it. To the point we started the evening with "Codenames" and, several hours later, ended it with "Codenames" (with nothing else in between). So why does it play so well? It's simple and fun (and often even funny), but at the same time very thinky, at least for this genre of games. And when you're trying to guess all the cards, there are no bad answers, really. Heck, you can play it strategically, if you want to! Risk a bit more when you're chasing the score or play safe when you're on the lead. This is sure to be a classic. Cannot recommend highly enough.

RATING: 9
21.11.2017

THE SILENT PARTY-GAME! :)
I truly love this game but I would hesitate to call it a partygame. What happenes usually is that the spymaster is desperately thinking about clues when it is his turn, the party aspect only enters during the opponents' turn. While your team is guessing you have to be silent but it's ok, since you are silently cursing them and thinking they are stupid due to their inability to see the BIG PICTURE. How they cannot see the hidden connection between those words??? How they ended up guessing words which clearly had nothing to do with your clues??
The playcer count is practically unlimited, and the more are in a team, the more chaos it ensures. FUN - FUN - FUN! And this praise is from a serious eurogamer, who was meh with Dixit for example....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Codenames adds a different type of game to my collection.  I'm more of a math type of guy and like games with theme - especially those where you build something (a city, an empire, a business, etc).  Now along comes Codenames that, the first time I saw it, seemed like a party game.  As a general rule, I'm not that in to party games ("Not that there's anything wrong with that.") but it's getting a lot of love around here so I figure I'll give it a try.  And you know what, I like it.

Why?  First, I am enjoying the logic puzzle of trying to communicate something to another person that makes them select certain words and not others.  I like trying to decide how to modify my clues depending on my partner (my wife, my 12 year old son, a friend in her early fifties).  All of these people have very different backgrounds and life experiences which make them interpret clues differently, so it's fun for me to try and customize my clues.  An example of me not doing a good job of this was using a clue of "Flash :2".  I was counting on the 17 year old I was playing with getting "Bolt" which he did, but he totally didn't get "Dance".  Being in my 40's and growing up in the 80's, most people had heard of the movie "Flash Dance" in my circle of friends.  After he failed to make that connection, I realized I had projected myself onto an 18 year old - one that was too young to have heard of the movie "Flashdance".  Doh.

I digress.  I will finish by saying that Codenames is a game that, in my experience, has broad appeal with its short running time and ease of understanding.  It's a game that I can play with people not typically in my gaming circle - my parents or other non gamer friends seem not to be intimidated by it.  Gaming with more people?  That's a win in my book.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is asymmetric beauty and provides an interesting puzzle to solve every time you play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.405
I agree with the consensus opinion that this is the best party game designed so far.

But you need people who are willing to have some discipline in how they play the game.  If the clue giver gives too many non-verbal signals (shaking his head "no", rolling his eyes, etc...) it can ruin the game.  But it's really a good simple game that get you thinking.

We played New Year's Eve 2015....and people were extremely engaged.....out of their chairs to get a better look at the words, etc...

Took it to a Christmas work party in 2016 and introduced it to a table of people.  Again it was a big hit.

Great discussion after each round as people are clarifying what people meant with each clue.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Description: A light word guessing, deduction, association party game, with two spymasters and their teams outsmarting each other.
Players: 4 to 8. Best with two teams of 3.

Impression: One of the best party games where two spymasters have the key to the 5 by 5 grid of different words and are trying to lead their teams to correctly guess only those words containing code names of their color. They are doing that by saying just one world not present on the board, and one number which is the number of associated words +1. Spymaster must be careful not to give a clue that is too close to a word of opposite color, or even worse, to a single assassin tile. I love this game for it reminds me of my favorite simple party game of Associations (Time's Up) which evokes similar feeling and scratches the same itch. Sometimes, it can cause analysis paralysis for a spymaster bringing a game to a stall, but the game comes with the hourglass to help in these situations. There is a little bit of luck involved as well, especially when you are a spymaster and have words like Robin, Hood, Arrow and Bandit.

Likes: That rewording feeling when your team successfully connects five tiles with one word. Number of possible girds, words and combinations offering huge replayability. Hilarious misunderstanding of some associations and/or ideas. 

Dislikes: Analysis paralysis. Too much silence for a party game. Feeling repetitive after 100 games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game can be fun with the right group and spy master.  I end up playing the spy master, which is a difficult job.  I tend to shy away from the game sometimes just knowing I'm going to have to do so much work.

It's fun though.  When we do play, it's always a great time.

RATING: 7
I love Vlaada's games in general, but I'm really not into party games. As a result, when I first heard about this game I pretty much mentally passed on it. But I changed my mind in December and bought it - the reasons being that it was really cheap, had got to a ridiculously high number in the BGG rankings (about 30), and after reading a few reviews I decided that this was a game that I could definitely enjoy and might well see some play in our groups.

And I was right. It's been enjoyed by everyone and has been a pretty popular end-of-night game. This will never be a game I consider "great", but it's very good in its place.

RATING: 5

My girlfriend absolutely loves this game, so I've promised that I will try it again for her - so possibly to be re-reviewed in future....

6/Nov/15 - After another play, it was slightly better and have improved my score to 5. But still don't see this as anything more than a time-filler.

13/Feb/17 - Having played the picture based version, I find Codenames Pictures is definitely better than the word based game.

RATING: 7.5
Codenames is a good game. It's not a party game however... sure it can accommodate a large group, and the rules are simple, but it's not a party game. People need to engage with it and it is not going to work for everyone.

That said, if people want to call it a party game, fine, but please don't invite me to your parties in that case. If you throw a gaming night together and Codenames is on the roster, then sure I'm your man.

RATING: 5
(+) Sublime ruleset that makes it instantly accessibly to a majority of people, gamers and non-gamers alike.
(+) Accommodates a large number of players.
(+) Rewards creativity and meta-gaming.

(-) Plays stagnate at low player counts (less interaction as you are solely codemaster and guesser on each team).
(-) Repetitive gameplay that can drag during the downtime while other players think of clues.
(-) Group and player dependent to get the maximum competitive experience from the game. But eh, it's billed as a party game after all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a game that MUST be played in the spirit of the rules.  And the spirit isn't always completely clear.  The formalism has huge gaps that can be exploited to trivially ruin the game.  However, I like games where I can explore the rules and push them to the limit, and I can't do that in a play-by-spirit game without risking accidentally cheating.  So, this dampens my enthusiasm.

In particular, it's highly ambiguous what information you can encode in the number you issue with your clue.

update:  I seem to like this game less each time I play it.  I really enjoy stressing the boundaries of what can be done within a rule system, and such behavior is simply not acceptable in a play-by-the-spirit game, and thus it just doesn't hold my interest after the initial novelty.

initial rating: 8/10

RATING: 7

+ [thing=215603]Tajniacy: Nowi Agenci[/thing]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like Codenames: Pictures more than this original plain text Codenames for 3 reasons:

1. Codenames: Pictures is language independent. That won't matter for many people, but I enjoy playing Codenames Pictures in Esperanto with Esperanto speakers, for example, for example, and I always play it with people who don't all have the same first language (playing the text version is less fun when not everyone understands the language of the word cards similarly well).

2. It neatly sidesteps the occasional debates and disagreements about whether a clue is legal, which come up in most word/clue type games like this and Taboo etc. (E.g. if the word is "science" can you say "scientist"? If the word is "hat" can you say "hate" or "hatch" or "that"? If the word is "car" can you say "chariot"? If the word is "goodness" can you say "badness"? If the word is "Richard" can you say "Dick"? If the word is "I" can you say "me"? etc etc etc.)

3. The cool well done surreal pictures are much more interesting & fun to look at than plain printed text.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The simplest and most obvious of ideas yields a really great party game; as always, the question is 'how was this never done in this form?'

RATING: 1.5
Yeah, I don't really get all the hype about this game. I guess part of the problem for me, being a teacher, is that it's too close to ESL educational games/activities I already use, but mainly, I just don't see the actual game in it. It's an interesting puzzle for the cluegiver if you like that sort of thing and a pretty boring co-op discussion for the other players.  Dixit is only ok for me but it's 100x better than Codenames.

Something is wrong with me that I see no redeeming qualities in this "game"? Some of my friends do enjoy it, so I'll give it half a point for getting to see their happiness, but I will avoid spending my gaming time on this trash at all cost.  I've decided I don't like Chvatil's designs no matter where they fall on theme or weight, from Codenames to Galaxy Trucker to Mage Knight.  He strikes out every time.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Codenames is a very popular game where two teams try to get their teameates to guess certain words in a grid that belong to their team.all before the other team guesses their words.  Players gues based on one of their teamates clues, but watch out for the assassin word... this will end the game immediately and cause the other team to win automatically.

Pros:  accomodates large player counts , fun competitive team play, easy rule set easy to teach and play

Cons:  no real depth of gameplay,

A játék egyébként jó (főleg, mert bárkivel játszható), de a sikerét nem értem. Illetve inkább a szerző nevének tudom be, mintsem magának a játéknak.
Nagy előnye, hogy akár házilag is bővíthető, kiegészíthető, még szabályokat is találhatunk ki hozzá.
Hátránya, hogy a kártyák kinézetébe nulla energiát fektettek. A tematizáltságot nem teljesen értem...
Az általános listán a TOP20 helyezést nagyon túlzónak tartom, de még a party game 1. helyezéssel sem értek egyet. Egyértelmű, hogy ha ez egy noname szerzőtől jön, akkor elsikkad a "futottak még" kategóriában.
Biztos, hogy sokat lehet vele játszani, de az sem tiszta számomra, hogy 4+ fővel mennyire jó a dolog. (Ez is olyan megerőszakolás szagú nekem.  up: most rápillantva a szavazatokra, 6 fővel előbb ki kellene próbálnom...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice creative brain-burner (for the clue giver). The selection of mundane words sort of break the theme, and I think they should have playtested the words more to find a slightly better selection. Even though there are 25 words on the board, you only have less than half of them that you must reveal, so the odds of finding two of *your* words which you can give a clue for is much less than the board might suggest, and you may have to veto your choice for a clue because it might fit an opponent's card. If you're ahead in the late game, you can anti-climactically win by giving obvious clues for only one card, rather than needing to give a clue for two cards (which you might not be able to do, anyway, since you have fewer cards to reveal towards the end of the game, and they are unlikely to be similar because you've already revealed the similar cards at the beginning of the game). Otherwise, it's a good party game to wrap up a game night with.

*****

I just have something of a problem with how difficult a clue becomes when you're going from one to two words. It's still an enjoyable challenge, because it's a unique *creative* brain-burner. Perhaps a tighter pool of words that made clues a little easier would help.

The words themselves seem to break the theme a bit. I feel like a contestant on a game show more than a sleuth or spy, unlike many of the other deduction games out there. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game, yet I doesn't give me a 'party game'-vibe...

Perhaps it's because [thing=38713]Time's Up![/thing] is my benchmark for what a party game should be, due to all the boisterousness and laughter it brings forth with my friends. Codenames doesn't quite provide that same experience, as people tend to get more 'thinky' in this game. It does provide some hilarious moments, though (I'll never forget the time someone started the sandtimer on her husband - and teammate - because he was guessing too slowly).

Finding the best clues to give your teammates is a joyful experience, and Codenames plays great with gamers and non-gamers alike.

RATING: 10
The best and freshest party game to come along in a long time. It manages to avoid the pitfalls of these designs in just about every direction. It's not really goofy and so doesn't require someone to make a fool of themselves (not always a bad thing, but limited in its appeal). But neither is it so difficult to grasp that it can only be played by gamers. 

Instead we have the most original and accessible game to come out of the hobby in a long time. This is already becoming a hit in the mainstream market, and will probably go down as the biggest hobby gaming hit since Apples to Apples.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Swedish edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't always give 10 star reviews.... but when I do, they are for the game 'Codenames.'

It brings me great joy when a game like this comes along - pretty much universally enjoyed, easy to learn, approachable to a wide range of people, and a perfect blend of fun & strategic.

Pros:
-Brilliant concept, huge satisfaction in giving a great clue (and in correctly guessing!)
-An element of (fun) intensity due to the presence of the assassin word (and the possibility of inadvertently giving clues for an opposing team's words!)
-The occasional opportunity to give a clue that hints at something only your partner will know, or that approaches the word in a particularly innovative way (though I am personally notorious for trying to stretch things TOO far and trying to be TOO aggressive when giving clues...)
-Love that the grid configurations are pretty much endless, when you take into account the different configuration cards, the different ways they can be oriented, plus the natural mixing of the words on the grid, etc.

Cons:
-You do have to be careful not to make it painfully obvious which card(s) you are looking at, particularly as the playing field gets narrowed down
-If you play a ton, you do start seeing the same words pop up - thankfully, there are tons of different combinations (so the connections themselves will typically be different), but we have indeed found that, if you play with the same group over-and-over, some clues tend to get repeated (for the same word(s)). Bring on a straight-up expansion pack!!
-You do have to really keep the group honest in terms on not reacting to things, commenting on what they really meant by a given clue after it is guessed, etc. (since you want to keep it up in the air as to whether the intended words were actually guessed as intended, or if the guessers just got lucky with what they picked!)

I personally prefer this game with 4 people, but it can also work with 6 or 8 (though we've seen it result in some more intense disagreements with 6-8.... particularly when the guessers are divided on which word to pick!! It can make it interesting though.... ;) )

All-in-all, a great game that you absolutely should pick up if you haven't already.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
I love party games, but very much dislike gamey party games. If I"m playing a party game, I want it to be silly, fast, loud, fun, with acting, and revealing of people. Gamey party games seem like frankensteins to me. If I want deduction I'll play a euro.

Not being able to look at people's eyes for fear of revealing clues, no small talk. It also bugs me when other players are responsible for defining the boundaries of the gameplay, my ability to play well completely dependent on someone else's ability to make word clues. We're playing a game within the unnecessarily small space of a person's preconceived notions and imaginative limitations as opposed to a set of game rules. I guess I'm saying it's too much like Pictionary for my tastes. A recipe for frustration.  

played it, disliked it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Delightfully easy to explain and launch into with just about anybody - almost any age and any level of gaming interest. Wonderful fun coming up with the clues and being on the other side trying to guess them. Deciphering the clues can lead to some good conversation and a lot of laughs.

There's lots of player interaction as teammates discuss what they know about the spymaster (warning - it can get hilariously personal), 400 words and many agent combinations to mix games up, and a neat timer nudge along mechanism to politely prod anyone dawdling on their turn.

This is the best group game I've played and it makes for a terrific gift for families. Winning is secondary to coming up with a really good multiword clue. But if you like the game bit then there's pressure you can apply to your opponents to catch up, a timing aspect as you wait until giving some clues (based upon other words confusing your team while they're still available), and if you really concentrate then some clue reading on your opponent's turn.

Children will learn some new words, a lot of synonyms and it's a good, fun mental exercise for everyone at the table. One game takes about 10-15 minutes and you'll have a hard time stopping at just one. Every house should have a copy.

RATING: 6
The silent party game! Heh. 

I was having a hard time playing it (cataracts, will get fixed they say) - so it was hard to grasp the whole field of words and think around them. 

It is an interesting mind scape - you try to combine doublethink with risk taking. You can go for more words, but it's risky and a question of how much will I be understood. I ought to play it more, but it seems that differences in logic and perception are more noticeable than in Time's up. You could use the game to get to better understand how other people are thinking. 

Ultimately I'm as bad at it as with Dixit - I'm too blunt or waaay too abstract. I can make connection faster than most people do, and they can't follow! Dang. Understanding other people's clues is easier. Might be an interesting exercise for me after all, understanding other people' thought patterns.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Codenames is a rather smart word association game with few bells and whistles. Spymasters have to make their teammates guess words in a grid by giving one-word clues. These clues have to be carefully considered so as not to overlap with the other team's words, or even worse, that of the assassin's. 

The spymaster's role is tougher (and arguably more fun) as she has more variables to weigh when picking clues, so groups might want to play consecutive games with roles rotated. Another caveat is that there isn't a lot of table talk due to the nature of the game – one word clues typically don't generate a lot of discussion, and the spymasters have to keep a straight face consistently. It's still upper-tier party game material though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Factor 	 Rating
Board design/layout?	0.75
Component quality?	0.75
Do I enjoy the theme?	0.7
How is the overall fun factor?	0.75
Are the mechanics implemented well?	0.85
How does it work solo?	 0.0
Does/will the family like it?	0.7
How easy are the rules?	0.9
Want to play soon?	0.8
Is this an amazing game?	0.7
Total 	 6.90

RATING: 9
Played this one time at an Uncle's Games demo and PAX Prime and I was totally hooked! I love word based games and this is the most challenging and rewarding I've ever played, although how well you do really depends on understanding the frame of reference of your game partners, even more so in other popular word games like Taboo or Catchphrase. 

The dependency on understanding your partner's knowledge can be frustrating at times when you think that obvious connections aren't being made, but sooo satisfying when your team is clicking and the guesses are flowing! My favorite new word game.

RATING: 5.7
Okay, I'll admit: I am not very good at Codenames. That alone doesn't justify my rating though. There are many games that I'm rather bad at and that I still rated at 7 or higher.
I guess I had more fun with those than I had with Codenames. Maybe it's because that there is 'only' player interaction and the theme-less quizz mechanic here. Other games I'm bad at alow me to tell stories about it, being thematic maybe.

Considering how highly rated this game is in general I might not do it justice with my low rating, but on the BGG rating scale (which is actually 'defined' by how much one would like to play a game) I really can't go any higher right now.

It's still at a place where I would play it given the opportunity and I hope I might end up increasing my rating at some point.

RATING: 8.5
2-8+ players

My biggest complaint is that the game breaks if the spymasters aren't playing along. For new players the concept of not being able to say ANYTHING, other than clues for the duration of the game is often incomprehensible, and I don't like being the party pooper who says that "It's cheating to act surprised when your team guesses a word you didn't mean for them to."

But other than that complaint, the game is great.  

Plays: 20+

RATING: 7
[2015-10-23]
Két csapat játszik egymással, mindkettőben választanak egy főnököt, aki próbálja rávezetni a csapattagokat a kitalálandó szavakra. Véletlenül, mátrixszerűen rakunk szavakat az asztalra, ebből a kezdő csapathoz 9, a másikhoz 8 tartozik. Egy véletlenül választott lap megmutatja melyik szavak tartoznak a csapatunkhoz, amit csak a főnök lát, feladata egyetlen szóval egy körben minél több saját szó kitalálására rávezetni a csapata játékosait. Az a csapat nyer, aki leghamarabb eltalálja az összes saját szavát vagy a másik csapat belefut az egyetlen rossz szóba, amit nem lehetne tippelni. A játék ötletes, páros számú játékossal működik igazán jól. Gyorsan lejátszható, lehet rajta gondolkodni. Sajnos nagyon nyelvfüggő, de tipikusan olyan játék, ami magyar szavakkal is tökéletesen működhet. Tetszett.

[2016-05-06]
Immár a magyar változattal játszva csak megerősítést nyert a dolog, magyarul is teljesen jól működik a dolog, sőt hárman is jól játszható. 4 fölött viszont igazából csak párosan jó, hogy kiegyenlített legyen a két csapat.

RATING: 8
As far as party games go, there are definitely more exciting titles, but I find Codenames to be quite enjoyable. With 6-8 players, this game really shines. The discussion for the teams is the best part and it's always fun to see if your guesses are correct. I think that a time limit needs to be strictly enforced as the game can become tedious if you're waiting for the other team to think of a clue and guess. Also, I find the boring one or two word clues to suck the fun out of the game. There should be a 3+ limit on the words you use as it challenges you to be creative and take some risks. If you working with a more cerebral crowd, Codenames is definitely a good choice.

RATING: 9
Brilliant. Deserving of being the best party game out there. Divide up into two teams, each team has a cluegiver and has to give a single word clue to link one or more of the words out on the table. The clues are maddeningly difficult to give, as you have to see if your team can think like you in connecting the dots, much as it can be on the other side to decipher the clue that was given. Truly just a fun, great party game, and something I'll always be up for.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Codenames is not a party game in the conventional sense.  It may be a party game in that large groups can play it, and there are elements of teamwork and competition.  But this game is more serious, more cerebral, and has more downtime than almost any party game available.  In theory, the downtime should be a major drawback.  Ambiguity in the rules should be another.

Yet Codenames might be the [i]best[/i] party game available.  There are several reasons for this.  First and most importantly, everyone seems to like it.  I have not found anyone who dislikes the game.  This is remarkable given the wide variety of settings and player counts at which I have played it.  Second, it promotes enough thoughtfulness in play to satisfy strategy gamers while remaining entirely accessible to everyone else.  The rules ambiguity is not a real problem.  Gamers will pay more attention to the rules than others, and groups will deal with disputes as they arise, but they rarely do.  There is a spirit to the game that everyone seems to understand.  Third, everyone is always engaged.  Downtime is filled with tension and curiosity.  While one team is taking their turn, the other is thinking or obfuscating or making snide remarks.  What happens adapts with the group.  It is never dull.  Lastly, like Dixit Codenames provokes insights into how other people think.  It brings people closer together.  What more could you ask for from a board game?

Incidentally, I think it would work as well with asynchronous online play as face to face, though you would lose the interaction of face to face play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game - great with gamers and non-gamers alike. I enjoy both clueing and guessing and think it works well with many player counts (although teams of 2 or 3 guessers to each codemaster probably work best).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Several plays with 4 and 6.

A great thinky style party game in the Password family, but with teams. Very simple, and very fun. The 6er game may be even better than 4 since you get to talk to someone about your options -- otherwise, there's a lot of silent staring going on! And it's a lot more fun than Password, which can be too thinky and too difficult. Plus, having the challenge of choosing your teams words and AVOID the Assassin and the other team's ... great design!

[b]--- Summary ---[/b]
Divided into teams, each with one Spymaster (clue giver). Create a random 5x5 grid of words. The Spymasters secretly look at a card which tells them:
- which team (red/blue) is first (and must find one extra 
- which of the words belong to each team
- which is the Assassin
Spymasters alternate giving one word clues, along with a number n. Their teammates then select words, up to n+1, one by one:
- if your team's, put your marker on it and continue (if you like)
- if the other team's, put their marker on it; your turn ends immediately
- if neutral, your turn ends immediately
- if Assassin, your team loses immediately

The first team to find all their words wins!

RATING: 9.5
This is an utterly fantastic game.  Simple, relatively deep and deeply engaging, while maintaining near infinite replayability in terms of card combinations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fantastic team party game.  The  game is played with two teams trying to find their spies out of a list of random codenames.  Each team has a spymaster that knows which affiliation each of the spies is.  As well as spies for both teams some codenames refer  to civilians that aren't affiliated with either team and one is the assassin which will cause either team to lose immediately if identified.

A team's turn is played much like the classic game show Password.  The team's spymaster will say a single word and a number.  The number refers to how many of that team's codenames on the grid relate to the word said.  So if two of the codenames are "hamburger" and "spaghetti" for example the spymaster could say "food, two".  However, you need to be careful because other words on the grid could relate to that clue.  In one of my games the opponent spymaster said "Asia, one"  trying to get his team to guess "India".  However, "Beijing" was also a codename on the board and it was one of our teams spies so he gave us a point by accident when his team identified that codename.

When a codename not belonging to one of your spies is identified, play passes to the other team.  The game ends when either one team identifies all their spies or the assassin is identified.

This is a clean, clever, and fun game that I will always be up for playing.  I will play either role but I do personally think the spymaster is a lot more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very brilliant game.  Has been an absolute hit with everyone I've introduced it do.  Foundation game in my collection.

RATING: 6

This is obviously easier if your team shares your random knowledge or have known you a long time, but this limits who you can successfully play this game with.

RATING: 2.5
It's pretty tame as a party game. The spymaster takes a while to give is clue and then sits there in silence. The others argue a bit and pick the codenames who are mostly obvious. The party element didn't come up much in my games.

The game is as fun as the skill of the spymaster. And it's only really fun when you're the spymaster as the guessing part is as fun as Battleship or Guess Who.

I get the initial buzz because it's still a innovative simple design, but I don't get why you'd want to repeatedly play this. Once you "get" what the game is about, there's little replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Word/party game where players split into two teams, each with a spymaster and a number of guessers. The spymaster must give his team a clue like "airlift 2", meaning that two of the 25 word cards laid out on the table belong to that team -- "plane" definitely, but what else? Perhaps "sky", ... no, "Berlin".

Guessing wrong normally just ends the turn, unless the wrong guess is the one card which means instant failure.

It can be very tough on the spymasters, and the complaints about downtime aren't unreasonable -- it's definitely possible for someone to sit there for quite a while agonizing over the best choice of clue. Mysterium is a good comparison: Codenames gives more more players the opportunity to give clues, which is good, but giving those clues is harder as there is much wider scope. Mysterium's clues are probably more thematic (dream logic) and I enjoy the interpretative possibilities more, but the free association of words does allow for the same sort of tenuous connection.

An instant classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the best party games out there. A lot of replayability, and a plenty of strategy involved.

RATING: 8
A great party game.  Very simple, but can be tough to master, having to say just the perfect word.  Playing with the timer is best!

Probably the only negative experience I had was with two spymasters that kept saying one word examples.  It just wasn't very imaginative and it took the whole stressful guessing out of that game, trying to stretch the meaning and purpose of one word to apply to only the words on your team is where the game is at.

For almost a completely different experience, you can use the app with a timer.  I love the super fast rounds where your team is frantically trying to figure out what you meant.  It totally changes the pace, stress and feel of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great, great game. Chvátil does it again, and brings out the easy to teach, engaging to play filler Codenames.

Basic premise is simple: try to describe an association that covers your set of words as much as possible, without the association triggering any neutral or (worse) opponents' or (even worse) the assassin card.

Sounds simple, but is so hard to do elegantly. Spymasters have a really tough time here, while players do have that tension of assigning probability to each association in hope to trigger any 'correct' ones first. As one wrong move and your turn (or even the game) is immediately over.

Great game with huge replay value, can see expansion packs being brought out for this that take the game into a themed direction.

Requires 6+ persons to shine and is more of a 'brainy' filler, but it fills that spot very well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
An excellent game to play with everyone.
It is great for people who have no experience with games, and do not like rules. Very easy to learn, everybody can guess words.
And here comes the best part of it, it is an excellent game for experienced gamers, because when you sit as spymaster there is no limit on how long one can theoretically think about the best one word codename for your agents (you should of course not spend to much time thinking). This makes it fun for both casual gamers and people who like to twist their minds.

Not a game I would play with my dedicated gaming group on our gaming nights, but one of my favorite "casual" games.

RATING: 8
12/22/16: ~Hype Detensifies~ 9 to 8. I find myself knowing this game works so well with groups, especially non-gamer ones, but feel that fact jives so well with everyone that we never play anything else. Codenames is like the "Top 40" of contemporary boardgames...

7/24/16: 10 to 9. Lately this game has devolved into a slower experience. Where players sit and wait for far too long for the codemasters to come up with a clue. Setting timers makes a "fun casual" game feel too strict, plus leads to uninspired clues. Still a super accessible game though.

12/20/15:Makes people who typically turn their nose to games become obsessed for hours on end. Enough deduction for veterans to be satisfied, simple enough concept and rules for even the greenest of noobs. Game can be taught in literally seconds, especially if most already know how to play. Nearly infinite replayability. Virtually everyone realizes how big of a hit this game is after only a single game.

I like it, but I don't get the extremely high rating this game gets. It is very good and lots of fun, but I don't think it's one of the best designs ever.

RATING: 6
Codenames is quite fun and Vlaada remains one of the most creative and original designers in the field. Codenames is wonderfully simple and yet has the potential to be both brilliant and tense. I thoroughly enjoyed being the spymaster, but being a regular spy afterwards with a little anticlimactic and after 2.5 plays as a spy, I was ready to move to something else.

That's not to say it isn't a wonderful design, it just doesn't have quite the same magic that his very best designs do.

Update: I think I just seem to have a lot less fun playing this compared to everyone else.

Rating down from 7 to 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I had a very frustrating experience playing this game (well, it is actually a Remote Associates Test developed by Mednick in 1962).

It is not easy to come up with hints for 2 or 3 words.
While thinking about them, other people get annoyed because of the long wait between turns.

People also give hints, like "this might be a stretch, but...", or even watching their eye movements. The rules warn against it, but you can't help it of course. They should have included some sunglasses with these mirror-coated glasses so that you could not see the eye movements.

If mindsets do not agree, even single-card clues can go wrong, imagine that!

After every game, serious discussions about what really was meant with the clues.

Since I will not ever play this horrible game again, I give it a "2" according to BGG rules...

Thank goodness there is an easy way out: just give a single-card clue for the Assassin. This will end the game and you can move on to a better one!

RATING: 9
This game is excellent.  Seems so far to have great replayability, it's a simple game, but it lets you try to think out of the box and get on a wavelength with your partner.  

So far I'm loving it.  Don't know how it will hold up over time, but it's quickly shot up my play list and I'm always happy to bring it out some more.

The only real hinkiness in the rules is the whole part about keeping a straight face, and not giving anything away.  Of course it's essential to play a straight game, but it's hard not to high five your partner if he gets what you were trying to go for on something brilliant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Taboo for the 21st century. Lots of fun. Once your group gets a feel for it, it should alternate between the brow-furrowing, eyes-down silently for a few seconds kind of fun, and either simple celebration or playful yelling: "What kind of clue was that? 'Good 2'?"
Yes, it's another simple-concept party game, but the little details feel so clearly thought up by an experienced, talented /game designer/, and that sets it apart. The way the first team has an extra word to deal with for no reason other than balance, or the system that allows players great options-- the structure of the clue mechanic is less alienating than Pictionary or Charades, yet not as arcane as most trivia games. It isn't closed off to people who aren't good with trivia or drawing or performance, yet still rewards creativity, knowledge, and player familiarity as much as any classic party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like it. Not well enough to purchase a copy, but it's entertaining. I definitely prefer to be the one giving clues.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Definitely a great game worth the merit of being BGG's #1 Party Game! Very easy to learn and can be explained really quickly! No one game will be the same with a huge amount of words and also the way teams perceive their clues. Had so much fun with nearly every group I introduced it to. The co-op mode is the best way to teach the game, but remember to purposely mention a clue that can go both ways. It helps to in demonstrating how words can be perceived differently.

RATING: 7
Solid game and good for playing with the family or at a party.  The great part of it is the use of only one word as a clue!  How many times that has tripped us up while playing.  Very fun game.  For the younger players that might not know some of the clues on the board we take a second before starting and have the younger players ask questions about words on the cards so that we make sure they know what they are!  Just a tip when playing with younger players.

ΑΓΓΛΙΚΗ εκδοση
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
While I typically don't gravitate towards party games, I picked this one up to play at a 007 themed birthday party for my mom.  It was superb, and we continued to play it with the family throughout the course of the holidays.

This game puts the pressure on the 'codemasters' of 2 separate teams to get their respective groups better word association clues than the opposing team.  25 cards with nouns are placed in front of both teams for the captains to work with.  The game provides the codemasters a very high pressure job, while the rest of the team is left to debate the meaning of the clues given by the codemaster.  

One of the most satisfying parts of the game is when a round is over and the captains can reveal their thought processes with the clues they chose to give.  Great game, and very easy to have fun with it.  So far when I have brought the game out, the entire group will ask for 2-4 more rounds after the initial first, taking turns being the codemaster for their team.  Few games allow for the amount of accessibility this game brings to the table, pleasing gamers and non-gamers alike.

RATING: 7.25
On one hand this is the one of the most thought intensive and suspenseful games around, and on the other it is a fun party game where you guess cards based on clues...just depends on what side of the cards you are on. A really fun game that everyone we have played with has really enjoyed, including us. It is funny to see someone who was a guesser berating the cluegiver take on the spymaster role and either give a bad clue due to "tunnel vision" or realize just how daunting the task can be. Always great for laughs and you feel like you accomplish something each time you play.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really seems like a 6-player-only game (or possibly good with 8 players too, but I haven't played that way yet). After my initial 4-player game I didn't see what all of the hype was about, feeling like it was just an okay party game. But the 6-player game really opens things up. You have another person's perspective to help with deciphering clues, and as the clue-giver you have two people who can hopefully correctly figure out your clue. The game also has a really smart way of handling the first-player advantage (the start team has to essentially get one more point in order to win).

[b]Player Count Verdict: 6, 8[/b]
You need even-numbered teams, and you want more players, so the game is best with 6 or 8.

Update: After several more plays, this game just keeps getting better. It can be incredibly tense as the clue-giver, as your teammates discuss whether or not to pick a card that you know if the assassin. Really fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

But they LOVE Codenames: Dixit! Totally breathed new life into both games. Great great great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am mildly surprised at the great heights that this one has reached on the BGG rankings simply because I don't understand what this is doing so much better than other similar party/word games.

That said, it is unique and definitely fun. I have had nothing but great success with all groups I have tried this with so I have no problem with the ranking. I'm just surprised.

This could actually surpass Dixit as my go-to party game if only because it so easily accommodates larger numbers. (Dixit is still cooler though).

Update: My rating has slipped a bit from an 8 to a 7. I am a little tired of it, but I do understand its high ranking. It is always wildly successful when I introduce it. So much so, that I am hesitant to do so because it means it will be constantly requested and, as I wrote above, I am a little tired of it.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 5
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 4
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 5


Overall - 4.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Party
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Codenames is essentially a party type word game in which you are attempting to solve the riddle of uncovering your teams agents - each represented by a single word - on a 5x5 grid of cards.  In actuality,  what this game has done,  is solve the age old riddle of longevity in the party game genre.

There has always been one caveat attached to most of the glowing reviews one might read,  concerning the party game genre - and that is - the fun contained within,  always came with an expiration date.

Take for example,  a highly popular party game - and one of my personal favorites - Wits and Wagers.  While being a great game,  it has a finite amount of cards,  which once you become familiar with,  render them essentially useless.  It is hard to deny the fact that this problem is basically inherent in the genre itself.

Codenames deftly skirts that issue by using 25 cards at a time.  Because of word associations,  the variable mix,  the key cards and the orientation of those cards - the usual stigma that is affiliated with this type of game - disappears,  like a stack of chips at a casino.  Add to that,  the fact that there are no definitive answers - that everything relies on individual interpretation - and you have stumbled upon something that is truly unique for this game model.

If all this game managed to do was break the mold,  it might deserve accolades for,  at long last,  simply performing that feat.  But there is more on display here than that...much more.  Beyond it's near limitless replay value,  there is much fun to be unearthed in that small box of sparse components.

This quickly became my number one word / party game of all time - although if you don't have an affinity for words,  I suggest you proceed with caution.  The game system itself,  is ingenious and versatile enough to allow one to widen it's scope.  

  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Best party game, in my opinion. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Sometimes hits well, sometimes falls flat.  Play with at least 4 and play with an even number.  Great well designed party game.

:nostar: sometimes it seems that you can just get stuck and not be able to combine any two words into a clue, and giving clues for just one card isn't much fun

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
English Version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Codenames is a new party game that I've wanted to try for a while now. I was pretty sure that I'd like the game as it falls into a category of party game that I like... ones where you give clues to get your team to guess the right word.

What's unique about Codenames is that there is a 5 x 5 grid of words that is visible to both teams. Each team has a spymaster. Both spymasters can see a card that shows which words in the grid are for the blue team, red team, neutral or the deadly insta-death assassin card. On a team's turn, the spymaster gives a one word clue and a number. The number tells the team how many words in the grid the clue applies to. Then the team has to guess word by word, which words match the clue. They can guess as many words as the number that was given and one extra guess (to try and get previous clues). If they get a word correct they cover it with their team marker (either red or blue). As soon as they get a word wrong the turn is over and it is the other teams turn. If the wrong word was the other teams it gets the appropriate marker on it, and if it was a neutral word it gets a beige marker on it. When one team gets all their words correct the game is over. Or if anyone guesses the assassin word, they instantly lose.

The game is a lot of fun. It's challenging to come up with clues that match multiple words without matching the wrong words. Interestingly, the opposing team can help you out... if they guess a word for their clue it will be covered (right or wrong) and so is out of play. Maybe you wanted to give garden as a clue for slug, grass and stick, but were worried that your team would guess yard in error. When the other team guesses yard, your clue is now perfect. The hardest part of the game seems to be when the spymaster doesn't realize that their clue might apply to words they didn't mean them to. Sometimes this is just an oversight, sometimes it is because they didn't go as deep as the team did, and sometimes it's an association that they just didn't know. In our game one player had never heard the expression "to pound sand".

The game is a lot of fun and does something new in the word association party game genre. It encourages you to be clever in trying to tie multiple words to a single clue... something that only occasionally happens in other similar games. I like what this adds to the genre and look forward to playing it more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
