=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Insert?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Want in Trade denotes silica gel protection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[floatright][ImageID=2582929medium][/floatright][thing=178900][/thing] is a social deduction party game, in which players are split into two teams: red and blue, with one player of each team being the spymaster (the one that give clues and knows the board - which words are red spies, blue spies, bystanders and the assassin) and the others being the operatives (the field agents that try to crack the "code" (word) given by the spymaster, in order to try to find their own agents in the board - i.e.: using the clue to point to the cards that are the agents of the same color of the team). [thing=178900][/thing] also has a light memory aspect to it - those that don't like this, don't really have much to worry about. It plays quickly and is easy to teach and learn (it is a party game, after all). [thing=178900][/thing] has one advantage over several other party games: it doesn't provide loads of yelling. Finally, [thing=178900][/thing] works well for those that are more on the shy side, since the "social" part isn't as strong as those in [thing=147949][/thing], [thing=24068][/thing], [thing=41114][/thing] and [thing=151369][/thing], being closer of that in [thing=39856][/thing] - where the purpose isn't discuss, but "read" the purpose of clues.

[b]Rules[/b]
Are pretty light. 25 cards are used to forma 5x5 grid. Two teams are formed, with one player in each team assuming the role of Spymaster - this will be the player that will give clues to the others of the team. One key card shows wich cards in the 5x5 grid are spies (and of which color), bystanders and the assassin. The goal of the game is for the team to find all the agents of the same color in the board, by poiting the words connected to them. The first team to find all the agents wins the game. But the teams are also trying to not hit the assassin - the team that does this loses immediately.

The clue given by the Spymaster must be of a single word and a number. The word will (hopefully) lead the team to connect it with one or more words on the board. The number has two purposes:
a) it indicates how many words on the board are, even slightly, connected to the clue;
b) the number of guesses the team has is the number given +1. But the team can only keep guessing if they are chosing right, by finding their own agents (pointing to the cards that are of the same color of the team).

So, say I'm the Spymaster. I could give the clue "Board 2". Then my team would look at the table and see:

[c]regular public    ingredient  cat	   line
bash	unity	   person     afternoon    full
dance	fill	   tax	      wife	   anger
oxygen	delivery   geology    fish	   shut
ashcan	arithmetic chain      survival     pork
[/c]

Now, which words you think are connected with "Board"? The Spymaster said "2", so, for him, at least two words fill the bill (or, maybe, in a previous turn, he said a clue that the team didn't got completely, so the Spymaster might have said 2 in order for the team to choose right for "Board" and use the 2 extra guesses in order to pick the cards they didn't understand at first, but, now, they do). Of course, the "connected" is relative with the person that gave the clue.

But lets say the clue was really for two words on the board. So, for instance, for one person, the "Board" clue might connect with "bash" (the leader) and "cat" (in the sack). For another, it can be for "ashcan" (Pete, an investigator from [thing=15987][/thing]) and "unity" (a hero from [thing=102652][/thing]). For a third could be "oxygen" (because of [thing=72225][/thing]) and "wife" (multiple reasons). For a fourth "anger" and "pork". And so on. The key to unlock this is to know where the Spymaster is coming from and what he/she might be thinking and, of course, if he/she considered what [b]you[/b] might think, your history.

If the team got the clue right, the team can continue guessing until they decide to pass, or pick a wrong card (choosing one that is a bystander or belongs to the other team), or until the team reaches the maximum number of guesses (number given +1). Then is the other team turn. The game continues in this back and forth until a team finds all their agents (the first team to do this wins the game) or until one team picks the word belonging to the assassin (instant defeat).

That is simply all there is to [thing=178900][/thing].

[b]Interaction[/b]
Is a the crux of the game. All the game is interaction. Not direct, mind you. One team don't act when the other is up. I can't interfere in your play, if we are in opposing teams. I am able to try some mind games though. However, the interaction I mean is between the Spymaster (clue giver) and the operatives (choosers).

We had a pretty good time trying to understand the clues. "What do you mean, godamit!" "That is THE best clue you can give?" And the confidence between the parts are important, and can also made your team crash and burn! One time I gave a clue I thought was awesome: "Backbone 2". I was going for "Head" and "Center" (yes, "Center" (of the body) - for me it made sense at the time). They first pick "Head". Great! Then, about this time or a little sooner, it dawned on me that the Assassin was linked to the "Doctor" word. Oh, shi... After the first guess the operative was a little lost, trying to understand my meaning. And sure enough the finger went to the "Doctor" card. And that was it, game over, we lost!

Therefore, there is important interaction between players, just not really with [i]all[/i] the people playing. [thing=178900][/thing] is not a team vs team like the one in [thing=142079][/thing] - the dispute isn't totally direct (the part where the teams "touch" each other is when one pick an agent of the other, and when a clue is understood by the operatives of the other team, so they know wich card to don't pick). So, not high confrontation here.

[b]Luck[/b]
Well, with wild guesses (and they are integral part of the game, as even with a "1" number being given, the operatives are allowed one extra guess) there comes luck. For instance: in our very first game, after the first clue was given, the operative couldn't understand it to zoom in to just one card. So he said "Well, I will try to guess one anyway". Of the 25 cards he could pick, he went directly to the one that was the Assassin! Defeat for the team in the very first choice. This was 100% pure luck for our side.

But this isn't a luck derived from dice rolls or blind draws from decks. Is comes from people. In the situation above the player [b]choose[/b] to pick a card at random - he could have passed. The same luck that comes from "will they understand?". They might. They might not. But the clue is always a choice made by the Spymaster, one that he must choose considering the people receiving it. The less he/she does this, the more luck the team will rely on to get it right.

So, there is luck, but it doesn't drive the game.

[b]Components and art[/b]
Are just OK. The cards with the words, to be clearer, contain, well, only words. But the design was well made, as is possible to read the cards from either side of the table, as the word in the cards are written twice, one upside down. Simple enough, but could have been overlooked.

All the art on the agent tokens is average, at best. Nothing remarkable. The box is medium-small, and is the perfect size for the game, with room for expansions (words are easy to come by) and fit everything with sleeves.

[b]Difficulty[/b]
To learn? Almost none. To play? Still really easy, with the difficulty not actually coming from the game, but in understand the hidden meaning of the clues, and, of course, coming up with the best clues, the the best ones are those that allows for more than 1 guess, linking two or more cards in a single clue, as the game is a race - the first to reach all agents on their side, so speed in finding them is necessary.

Is easier to give one-off clues - one that is directed to a single card. Notice I said "easiER" not "easy" as the limitation of a single word for the clue means no articles or prepositions to set up the word. For example, considering the words I used above, saying "the leader" could lead to "bash" (among savyy players) - but only "leader" might open more the road to words like "wife" (among most households), "public" or "person".

Mind you that,clue-given can specially induce a lot of AP to some, while they try to find the perfect clue, and this can lead to some stress, when the others are hurrying the other and calling for a clue. Some players might not want to be involved with this (but they can still play [thing=178900][/thing], but always as the operatives/choosers).

However, is this "difficulty" that is the heart and fun of the game. 

[b]Time[/b]
When we hit the Assassin, the game usually lasted around 15-20 minutes. But the times we went until one team found all their agents, it took longer, around 30 minutes. To give the clue and to try to crack "the code" of the clue weren't done quickly sometimes.

So, while I can't say that the official 15 minutes isn't completely wrong, it also isn't all that correct also.

[b]Theme[/b]
Yes, this part is seriously lacking. There isn't any real attachment with how the game work with the theme it has. Sure, it uses names like "spymaster", "operative", "agents", but don't be fooled by this. The theme could be anything:
- You are two crews trying to find the treasures of your country - England x France, Spain x Portugal, you name it. Find the sunken treasures in the sea, but stay away from the Kraken!
- You are two races fighting for survival, in order to do this, you must find planets in which you could live (while trying to not lead the others to planets where [i]they[/i] could live!). So, find planets to colonize, but be careful not to enter into the Blackhole!
- You are two teams trying to find first all the hidden easter eggs. Blue vs Red! However, you must not run into the Killer Bunny!

And so very many others re-themes, without changing a single rule of the game. If you are looking for a thematic party game, you won't find it here.

[b]Summary[/b]
[thing=178900][/thing] is a good and efficient party game. It knows the lenghts it wants to cover and do it well. The game doesn't over reach - it wants to be simple, quick, with low(but there)-confrontation of teams.

And, as psychology has proved, all it takes to make people competitive at each other, is to simply divide them into teams. "You are red, I'm blue, you are dumb and I hate you." So it will be given that people will try hard to win, not only for the win itself, but to do well in front of the friends/audience. To get ir right an obscure clue is great to feel accomplished - is a undeniable proof of smartness, above average inteligence and raw sexiness. Failure means turning into an outcast.

The game is made to accommodate up to 8 players, but it works well with less, maybe with less laughs and discussion, but with, well, play for the ones playing, since the challenge remains the same - pick a card. With more you just divide this with others.

Clue: recommended 1.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
I see the party appeal, but definitely not my type of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Excellent party game for big groups. Very fun if people don't take it too seriously and it is possible to freely drop out and come back during the game since the setup is so loose with a lot of people playing. Works very well with drinking and men vs women as always a blast. Easily best with 6 or 8. You can also play this with "serious" attitude --> clue givers think best possible clues for a long time but then the game is not nearly as fun as a pure party game (so i recommend that you play this without too much stress about winning) . Theme is easy for non-gamers to get into and rules are extremely simple but at the same time there is a lot of replayability.

RATING: 8
This is an excellent party game that requires a lot more brainpower than the average party game.  It is like a more interesting version of Password, it really takes a lot of concentration to come up with various associations between words.  The game is always different each time you play, and it's been a hit with every group I've played it with so far.  The only problem I've noticed is that the game can drag on when the clue giver can't think of a good clue (being the clue giver is difficult!).  It's a great game overall.

RATING: 7
Light, casual party game. Pretty fun, works best with 6+ but is playable at 4.
The most important element is the set of key cards, which show the Spymasters which card slots are on which team. If you don't like staring at a bunch of words, use the key cards from Codenames, but set up the board using cards from Mysterium, Dixit, or similar.

RATING: 8
Fun party game.  However, the game does demand that all players pay attention -- you can't really walk off to the fridge or snack tray when it's not your turn.  Easy to teach, easy setup, and quick play keep it entertaining.  The players I introduced this to all wanted to play again.  This is like the old 'Password' tv game show.  

Codenames is a competitive game between two teams.  I've only played this with four or five players.  Three is workable if the group can consider the clue giver to be a neutral party.  I'm skeptical that two players (playing against 'par') would be engaging.

There is no reason why a child couldn't play this, however the deeper your vocabulary, the better you will compete.

RATING: 8.5
VC再一次展现了他的神奇和他设计思路上的全面性，用一款拼字游戏征服了我。
这个游戏的规则非常简单，而且容易推给没有桌游经验的玩家，同时游戏规则自定义性非常大，每个人都能找到自己喜欢的题目，玩过的人都会期待下一次游戏！
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played a 2 player version. Clearly better as a team-based game. I can see the potential for this game, but again, with all party games, the success or failure of Codenames lies in the group. This game is language dependent, so in a mixed crowd with different English proficiencies, this game may fail or drag. Also, there is a trivia or cultural aspect to this game as well. So, again in a mixed crowd, this game may not work.

Overall, an excellent design. I wonder if visualization of clues to link all the codenames can be "improved" over time. This would indeed be a cool game if you can improve this aspect of "linking" obscure "clues".

Played with 4 and the game is good. Yes, it is not easy for some, but the "ah ha!" moments are priceless in this game. Some folks may not have an easy time visualizing the links and connections in the game and it can suffer from some cultural or language-dependent advantage like so many other word games, but in the end, the game is a winner!

RATING: 8

For me, this isn't as good as a party game as it is as a small group, competitive game. Which is odd, considering how much 'fun' people have when 'playing' it. 

I've decided I'd rather play this with non-gamers than gamers, as with gamers I'd rather be silly and have fun with something else to actually play, rather than just sit there shouting random words at people to put them off, fun as that is.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
HIGHLY recommended!  This game is relatively casual but does require some good thinking from the two codemasters and can be played quite seriously with the right crowd.  The only downside is how long the very first clues require and the very last clues require to come up with for most codemasters.  Even very good codemasters might delay the game excessively because they want to perfect their plan.  It is hard to set a time limit too because sometimes the options are either nearly non-existent or the only good clues overlap with the assassin or other players cards too heavily.  

My favorite experiences in this game have been playing it "pass and play" 2-player variant with my girlfriend (now wife) by setting up the gameboard and writing the clue down on a whiteboard so she can write her guesses in order of priority on the board and I can score it next time I go past and have an infinite amount of time to do my next clue.  2-player rules are in the rulebook and work well for having fun maximizing cluegiving and interpreting skills.  We have even played by picture message on phone updating the gameboard and texting clues and guesses.  Game speed varies a lot played this way and requires a dedicated space setup for codenames but this is just loads of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Must have party game for adults!

Best new party game I've seen in a while. Must have, and it's only around $17 on Amazon. Give one word hints to your partner or partners that connect two or more random nouns together. The partners on your team then try to guess your words and not the opponents'. Very simple yet captivating game.

RATING: 3
This game got a lot of buzz when it came out. I rushed right out and got it as soon as I could. I had a family get together a few days later and I was really excited to play it. We played a few staples before we got to Codenames; Cash N' Guns, Wits & Wagers, Spyfall. Then I unleashed Codenames on them. What a letdown. Everyone was having so much fun...Codenames put an end to that pretty quickly. I just don't get it. Every time I've played this game with people who have never played it before...one game is enough. I know there are people who like it, but for my money there are MUCH...MUCH better party games. Any of the other games mentioned above for instance.

RATING: N/A
Two teams compete to see who can make contact with all of their agents first. Spymasters give one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team.

4-8 (best 6-8)

Party game, word game, deduction, pattern recognition

RATING: N/A
Owner: Rachel Vacek
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Can't think of a better game to get a large group of people involved. It's so simple and quick to explain; team captain gives a clue and his team tries to figure out which words best associate with it. Other spy themed games wish they had such a streamlined deduction mechanic without devolving into a game of Guess Who. And that's not even getting into the staggering amount of setup variation within just the base game itself, let alone the other standalone variants.

On the downside, you do need to clarify the "flexible rules" with newer players so they don't unintentionally sabotage their team's chances with illegal clues, which can lead to some disagreement among players. A bad spy master or poor communication can also derail your chances of winning very quickly though that's a matter of player skill, separate from the flawless game design.

Bottom line: This game will be a permanent fixture in my collection
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Ugh.  This game is annoying, and the fact that it seems to have cross-group appeal between gamers and non-gamers makes it show up everywhere.  Clues are intentionally clipped and thus usually uninteresting, and there's little room for creativity.  You either think of the word, or you don't.  Furthermore, one player can really ruin a team's fun, either by giving bad clues or by dominating the guessing side.  And worst of all, this game has a tendency to drag as people overanalyze the clues endlessly.

I would be happy to never play this again, though I probably won't be able to avoid it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The fact that you can take such simple words and make them into such a compelling game is very impressive.  This is a word game where having a huge vocabulary isn't as important as being able to find that odd connection between seemingly disconnected words.

Sometimes the result of that connection is brilliant, but sometimes that clue that YOU think is brilliant makes no sense to your teammates.  Of course, this is best at 4+ players, but giving clues is so enjoyable that it's a pretty fun game with 3, and a neat activity with just 2 people.

RATING: 9
'Codenames' is one of my favourites. Admittedly, our team had a ropy start, and as with games like 'CSI Files', providing clues is more about knowing your fellow players as much as appreciating the niceties of opthalmology. I think reflecting on what clues can be given, as well as those that can't, may make future games easier to follow. The letter 'D' as in the connection to the word; day, falls outside the parameters but there are no hard feelings as we ended up on one clue left even though we managed to guess two grey tiles, to boot. We even threw in a few for our opponents as well! Good game as always and still the highest scoring UK Expo game within the club

RATING: 9
I have played this game many times with people who are new to gaming. The first reaction might be: “‘nah’, that doesn’t sound very interesting … a word game!?” And then after one or two games, it’s more like: “Wow! … Can we play again? … Where can I buy this fantastic game?” In brief, this is really an exciting and thrilling game that captivates everyone I have played it with. I love the way it makes your brain work in unexpected ways, trying to link two, three or even four words … EUREKA! You got it! And then your team gets it all mixed up – having completely different word-associations.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is quite an achievement, the small scale Holy Grail of "A party game that Jeff actually looks forward to playing". The rules are the epitome of simplicity and can be explained in 2 minutes, even in a room full of drunks.

The gist is one player tries to find a way to connect 8 or 9 randomly selected words using as few clues as possible, with each clue consisting of a single word and a number. The number represents how many of the random words are linked by that particular clue. His team then tries to guess as many words as they can (from the displayed list of 25 total words).

A second player and his or her team does the same, using the same set of 25 words, but with a different selection of the 8 or 9 words as targets. Then teams alternate attempts, eliminating words as they correctly guess them. The first team to guess all of their target words wins immediately.

This all sounds pretty easy, but there's a catch. One of the words is a trap. If anyone chooses the trap word, their team automatically loses.

It's a lot of fun and I have to say, being the clue giver is much harder than you might expect. Linking the words is fairly easy, but not also linking to words that belong to the other team or the trap word is much more difficult. Often you will focus so intently on creating a clever clue, you will miss an obviously wrong answer match, trapping your team.

The other thing I enjoy is how well it scales to player count. Usually the more eyes you can get on a puzzle, the easier it becomes to solve. Not this one...In fact, the more minds you add to the think tank, the more clouded the answers become. All sorts of questionable relationships start popping up, as more and more outlandish connections start to be made between the random words.

It takes about ten to fifteen minutes to play a game, but once you start it's easy to lose a couple of hours, especially when a metagame starts to form around different ways to link the words using movies, shared experiences and inside jokes. It's an awesome amount of laughs, but still manages to be a challenging an engaging puzzle. I would not feel bad about a copy of this being in every gamer's collection, from casual social gamer to heavy lifting GMT guy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Everyone was talking very highly of Codenames during Gen Con and every time I saw it I was underwhelmed. I didn’t quite understand the point of the game and never read too much into it and ignored it for a while, but eventually I just decided to buy it and make up my mind for myself and I am very glad I did.

I’ve played this with my meetup group five times now and two of those plays included the entire group and it was a blast. I enjoy playing as both the spymaster and their team and would be happy to play either. Crafting the clues is incredibly difficulty, but also a rush when you get one just perfect for your team.

The biggest problem is remaining straight faced as the spymaster and giving no clues about how accurate any guess is. No reaching for a card, no nodding or shaking of your head, no noises, no smiles, nothing. You have to sit there and be straight-faced, it’s a little exhausting. Still, the game is excellent and will be a go-to party game for a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This could be the best party game ever created.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Codenames is a great, simple party game.  It is quickly taught.  Very accessible for those that don't play board games.  It is a fun way to use your brain, have fun with some friends, and spend an evening together.

It is a word game, so it will fit some people better than others.  It also has the same issue that other word games do that the better you know your team members, the better you will be.  I have seen someone give a Harry Potter based clue that netted them a 4 point turn.  I've also seen a very simple sports based clue that was lost on the guessers, as they didn't follow sports at all.  So knowing the person you are giving clues to helps.  We normally mix up teams every game or two to keep it interesting.  

The words in the game are not that complex so there isn't really a big issue with having to know obscure words/terms like there can be in other word games.  

There is also a disparity in the game in the level of difficultly based on if you are giving or receiving clues.  The job for the person giving the clues is much harder than the one guessing.  It is best if those new to the game guess clues first before trying to give them.

One minor downside to the game is that it slightly unbalanced due to the starting player phenomenon.  The team that starts guessing first has to guess one additional clue to make up for the fact that they get to guess first (since it is first to guess all of their cards wins starting first is a large advantage).  Additionally, if the first team does get some of their cards right, choices are removed from the board possibly making clue giving for the second team a bit more easy (as some potentially dangerous words have been removed).  Even with both of these effects our experience is that the team that starts will win the majority of the time (80% in the games that we have recorded information for though the sample size is too small to be statistically significant at this point).  So while it is probably the best that could have been done, it just wasn't enough in my opinion.  

The reason that there is a disparity even with the extra card is that in most games, a team will score 1 3-point turn, then mostly 2-point turns after that.  With in mind, the starting team will win in 4 turns (3, 2, 2, 2).  The second team will win in 4 turns as well (3, 2, 2, 1).  Unfortunately since the second team goes second, they will lose.  So finding that one 3-point clue is key as is making sure there are 2-point clues lined up.  Pulling off 2 3-point turns is very hard so compressing the 4-turn win down to 3 is hard for the second team.  The second teams best chance of winning is a mistake by the first turn team.  

Regardless, it's still fun either way and people really don't care so much about if they win or lose.  It's still just fun to play.  Plus it is fun to win with a disadvantage so it makes winning from the second position more rewarding.  I remember a game where the second place team got had two cards left as did we.  I was unable to come up with a good 2-point guess so I looked at their two cards left.  They had "Thumb" and "Van" and didn't feel that I had to push for the win so I opted for the 1-point safe route.  Then the other teams clue givers says "steer" and I knew the game was over.  That second place win was very memorable.  We also had a game where we got a 4-point clue on the last turn to snatch a win away from a team that was certain to win without it.  So even though the odds might be skewed, it's still a blast and the skew can actually create great situations in a very short game that wouldn't be there otherwise.

Additionally there are ways to mitigate this effect through playing multiple games if you like.  You can play two games, one with each team starting first and then sum the scores of how many clues you got when the game ended to determine the winner.  You can keep a score per player and just allow teams to be random and see which person did the best that night.  Etc.  We don't care enough about who "wins" to do this, but it seems that there are reasonable routes to reduce the effect through multiple games.

I highly recommend this game for anyone.  New to games or not.  Fantastic time nearly every game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I normally avoid party games, but Codenames is at the top of the food chain.  Things I like:

Clues from previous rounds help partners - and opponents! - in later rounds.

The mounting pressure as one team falls behind.

Tenous connections between words, friends, and acquaintances.

Fighting ninjas.*

One minor drawback is that the game starts with an immediate lull while the clue-givers digest the word grid and ponder potential clues.  But one man's lull is another man's naptime.


*This could be ninjas fighting each other, or me fighting a ninja.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Theme/Art:
The spy theme works pretty well, the art looks fine, but it's both not that important as Codenames is a party game and the words on the cards are the most important part of it.

Production quality:
It's all small cards and light cardboard, which are fine. However, the hourglass isn't the best I've seen in a game. It's completely optional though.

Replayability:
There are a LOT of different word cards, which have a different word on each side, and each spymaster-card can be used at all four angles, so the combinations are endless.

Depth/Difficulty:
The game is explained in about 5 minutes, but coming up with good hints can be really hard.

Strategy:
You have to think of hints that lead your team to as many spys as possible, but keep them away from the assassin and members of the other team. The two player variant recquires a bit more strategy, because each round the spymaster has to choose an enemy spy to uncover.

Luck:
The cards and the spymaster card are random, but you can come up with good hints for pretty much everything if you are creative enough.

Codenames takes abou 15-30 minutes to play, depending on how long the spymasters need to think of their hints.

It is a phenomenal party game (although not for big parties, more than 8 players could get a bit much), the only downside I can think of are the downtimes when a spymaster takes a long time to think. You can use the hourglass in this case though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having played this game a number of times times, and being horrible at it, I still enjoy it a lot. It is such a simple design yet it is so difficult! You are at once at the mercy of the card draw and your ability to convey the clue to your team, but at the same time, you're at the mercy of your teammates being able to understand the obscure clue that seemed to make sense to you but ended up taking them down a completely different path than expected.

I'm not the greatest with "word" games but this is one of those social games that I enjoy quite a bit and one that has gone over well "gamers" and "non-gamers" alike.

RATING: 7
I do feel this game gets more praise than it deserves. I like it, but it isn't world changing. Good party game, gateway game, and honestly, my favorite word game. Fun, quick, and usually gets multiple plays right in a row. This is a game I will bring to a new group or one I am unsure about their grasp on modern board games.

Artwork- 6/10
Theme- 4/10
Mechanics- 7/10
Fun- 7/10

RATING: 7.5
The theme is rather pasted on and it is a game revolving around word association. However, it has immense replayability. It requires more rather than fewer players to play well. It also works better if one plays it with friends or relatives, rather than strangers. Component quality is above average while the artwork is simple but effective enough. The rules are really simple, so it can be taught in under 5 minutes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have Codenames, Codenames: PIctures and Codenames: Duet and I'm logging all plays under Codenames rather than adding extra games to my collection and dividing plays among the 3.

This one took me by surprise, I'm a bit burnt out on party and filler games but Codenames cuts through all of that. I like that it will play a big group, the rules are in no way esoteric and the theme is fairly neutral which makes the game very accessible.

I prefer words over the pictures.

Duet is really fun.

< October 2015

+ Codenames pictures &^ Codenames Duet

RATING: 4
Fun word-centered party style game. Can lead to some laughs, groans, and an overall decent time. Sadly I don't see the game working well in Swedish, given that we use compound words excessively, so our "one word clues" could with some trickery encompass all 8-9 cards that you want your team to locate.

I also don't know why this appeals so much to people, as it's too calm for a good party game, and not interesting, nor deep enough to be such a quite time. It's just not my bag.

RATING: 6
I don't particularly like word association.  I simply lack the type of creativity to do particularly well with it.  I also don't like games where there is substantial downtime where you can't be thinking about your next move. So... my first experience with Codenames was a complete flop.  When I finally played again it was with a much faster playing group and I saw a lot more of the fun of the game!  I'm not sure it would ever be my "party game" of choice... but I won't be actively avoiding it in the future provided there are always enough people for proper teams and we use a timer.

RATING: 6
An excellent and really fun word game that works great for medium to large groups :) I had a blast with this game. Trying to get into your partner's head while also trying to recall words which were used before is a wondrous combination. This game works great! Also, we tried it with a variation by using Cards Against Humanity answer cards in place of the regular words, and it was crazy! But really funny :)

EDIT: I've lost a lot of interest in this game over the last year or so. Phenomenal for the first good amount of plays, but I just don't really enjoy it like I used to.

RATING: 7
Clever word game by Vlaada himself.  It appears to be a party game but it isn't.  Early play in each round tends to get bogged down while players look for links between the 25 word cards.  Picks up speed as the game progresses but the next round grinds to a halt again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game is good in theory, and probably fine for people who are good with words/language, but as a math/science/numbers guy - I hated this. It was tolerable as a guesser (once there was actually something to guess), but it was just awful as the clue-giver. There's so many words on the board and you have to think of a phrase that suits your own words but not the opponent's, and it either winds up taking forever to go through all the words and come up with a good clue, or you just hurry up to move the game along and don't make much progress because the clue you give isn't as useful as it could/should have been if you'd had more time to think about it. This would be much better in a different format, like an online message board maybe, where you could drag the game out much longer and take several hours to come up with the clue. Trying to do it live in just a few minutes is just terrible because everyone is basically just sitting around waiting for the next clue, which is boring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After first 2 games: Feels like the game is always really intresting and challenging for the leader, but it felt a little boring (too easy) for the agents (guessers) at least when the leader gave only 1 hint everytime.
The problem is worse if there are more agents in the teams, because it gets easier when there are more brains to solve the puzzle(hint)given by the leader.

In my opinion the game is best with 4 players (2vs2) and next time we try the game with obligatory "2 hint rule" to add more challenge. 
I bet the game will be real fun after that mod :)
All in all easily the best word quessing game on the market! +++

RATING: 1
This is a fun party "game". it has variants for lots of different # of players. and I like the rating of win states at the end of the game based on how long it to to do the puzzle. All that said i have to give the game a one as it is not really a game, its a word association puzzle, that requires at least 2 people to attempt. 
Now if this was rating it as a puzzle or an "ice breaker" socialization tool, i would have to give it a solid 8. As is I have to rate it as NOT a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Word-game about linking multiple words together with a single clue. Players split into two teams, each with a "spymaster" who gives out the clues. The "agents" must then pick the words in the middle that link to the spymaster's clue. Tense and hilarious.

Theme: Secret agents
Mechanic: Word game
Ideal players: 4+
Length: Short
